title: Experiencing Architecture
requirements: UGEC1016 is double-coded with ARCH1320. ;Not for Architectural Studies Majors; and students who have taken ARCH1320[1330] or 2111.;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC1016 is double-coded with ARCH1320.) The course provides a general outline to architecture. The aim is to introduce architecture as a cultural phenomenon. The course will increase the student's awareness of the built environment as it exists all around. It examines a variety of spatial experiences encountered in exemplary places and buildings. The scope of the course is not limited to buildings alone, but includes cities and landscapes as extensions of architecture. The course introduces a range of topics, including the historical, symbolic, aesthetic, functional, cultural and green aspects of architecture.
outcome: To comprehend the discipline of architecture in relation to the broader contexts of history, culture and civilization.       To remember the key concepts and some significant works of architecture.       To analyze the relationship between architecture, city, and landscape, cultural memory.       To comprehend the design and building process of architecture.   To enrich students with direct dialogue with the architects/designers who have created the architecture.   To apply skills for clear expression in written and oral presentations.
syllabus: The course introduces a number of topics related to the conceptual and aesthetic aspects of architecture. Among the topics introduced will be the following:                    Introduction of Architectural Vocabulary        A Brief History of Hong Kong Architecture       Architecture through the Ages       Architecture and Culture       Architecture and Heritage       Green Architecture       The Design Process       The Building Process and Architectural Practice       China New Architecture        The course format involves regular lecture sessions, with occasional discussion sessions and short group presentations. The course may also include occasional field trips/excursions to selected sites in Hong Kong as well as some workshop exercises.
required_readings: 01. Architecture: Form, Space, Order by D.K. Francis, Van Nostrand Reinhold. New York (NA2760 C46) 02. Post 97 public architecture, Hong Kong, page 7-11. MCCM (NA4425 H85 H68 2005) 03. 'isms: Understanding Architectural Styles by Jermy Melvin, Herbert Press London (NA200 M45 2005)
recommended_readings: 01. Thinking Architecture by Peter Zumthor (Birkhauser)   02. The Death and Life of Great American Cities by Jane Jacobs   03. the City Shaped - Urban Patterns and Meanings Through History by Spiro Kostof

title: Understanding Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area
requirements: UGEC1120 is double-coded with GRMD1301. ;Not for Geography and Resource Management Majors; and students who have taken GRMD1301[1033].;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC1120 is double-coded with GRMD1301.) Since the establishment of the Special Administrative Region in 1997 under “One Country Two Systems”, the synergy between Hong Kong, Macao and the PRD has been renewed. With the recent Central Government's initiative of the development of Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area, there will be closer and mutually beneficial co-operation among cities in this economic region. This will reshape the socio-economic relations and the urban landscapes of the three places. Studying the changing relations of Hong Kong, Macao and the PRD will not only help students understand the dynamic socio-economic development of the Greater Bay Area as a rapidly growing mega-city region in the world, but also capture the latest transformation of the region. A wide variety of teaching and learning activities, including lectures, forums and video watching will be conducted to present a lively and comprehensive picture of the Greater Bay Area to students.
outcome: Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area is a rapidly growing and significant mega-city region in the world. This course will not only offer a broad coverage on various aspects of Hong Kong, Macao and the PRD development, but also place an emphasis on the intricate relationship of the three places. After completing the course, students will be able to:     describe the historical development of Hong Kong, Macao and the PRD;    explain why Hong Kong, Macao and the PRD are closely related and intermingled under the rapid process of globalization;    use examples to show how a place’s growth and development is associated with regional and global conditions;    relate knowledge to potential employment in the future;    diagnose the social, economic and environmental problems of the region beyond what is presented in the mass media.
syllabus: Lecture topics:   Getting to know Hong Kong and the Pearl River Delta •         Hong Kong, Macao and the PRD: The geographical setting and changing spatial relationship (香港、澳門與珠江三角洲:地理位置與空間關係轉變) •         From farming to manufacturing: socio-economic transformation of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (從桑基魚塘到世界工廠：粵港澳大灣區經濟社會變遷)   Economic aspect •         Foreign direct investment: angel or devil? (外來投資：天使或魔鬼？) •         CEPA and Greater Bay Area (CEPA 與粵港澳大灣區) •         Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area: a premier tourist destination (粵港澳大灣區:旅遊業新景象)    Social and environmental aspects •         Cross-border infrastructure development in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area: competition vs cooperation (粵港澳大灣區跨境基建：全面規劃還是各施各法？) •         Migration in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (粵港澳大灣區人口流動) •         From state to market: how to satisfy the housing demand in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (從國家分配到市場機制：如何滿足粵港澳大灣區人口的住房需求?) •         Environmental degradation – a necessary evil of economic growth? (環境惡化–經濟增長之必然代價？)   Governance and planning •         Planning sustainable cities and region in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (粵港澳大灣區城市與區域可持續發展規劃) •         One country, many systems: competition or cooperation in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area ‘一囯多制’：競爭還是合作？ •         Mega-city regions: the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area from global perspective (全球視野中的粵港澳大灣區城市群發展)   Two video watching and discussion sessions •           商機無限 •           走進大灣區。機

title: Thinking Gender: An Introduction to Women's and Gender Studies
requirements: UGEC1209 is double-coded with GDRS1001.;Not for Gender Studies Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2310, GDRS1001, GENA2192 or UGEC2653.;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC1209 is double-coded with GDRS1001.)  This course aims to develop students’ ability to analyze the everyday life through the lens of gender. Drawing on the interdisciplinary nature of Women’s and Gender Studies, the course will guide students to examine how gender works as one of the primary social organizing principles in the movies we watch, the housework we do, the behaviors we express and many other daily activities that have been routinized. The first three lectures will equip students with a critical gender lens by questioning biology and getting familiar with theories of gender role, socialization, gender schema, doing gender and queer theory. All concepts to be explored in class will be explained with reference to research. At the end of the course, students will come to understand how political their personal life is. In particular, the course hopes to inspire students to take part in creating social change for gender equality, which is in line with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to 1. recognize gender as a fundamental organizing principle of society; 2. describe how gender is constructed and in what ways it influences us at individual, national and global levels; 3. explain gender in various perspectives with sound justifications; 4. theorize cultural issues from a gender perspective 5. reflect upon their life and choices. 6. Consider changes in social practices and policies that can better address gender equality 7. Evaluate the barriers and challenges in achieving gender equality in diverse cultures

title: Japanese Culture and Society
requirements: UGEC1232 is double-coded with JASP1100. ;Not for Japanese Studies Majors; and students who have taken JASP1100, SOCI2103 or UGEC2260. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC1232 is double-coded with JASP1100.) The main objective of this course is to give students a general idea of Japanese cultural history and social background of modern Japan. Guidance leading to a better understanding of Japan will be provided.
outcome: 1) Students are expected to gain an understanding of the main areas of Japanese life including work, family, gender roles, marriage, and religion. They are expected to understand the ways in which Japanese see their own society in terms of economic growth, Japan's place in the world, social order, and political structure.   2) Students are expected to understand and be able to use a variety of social theories and perspectives in understanding Japan. They are also expected to have gained an understanding of how these same perspectives might be used to analyze their own society, or other societies which they may wish to study in the future.   3) Students are expected to develop a clearer understanding of their own values regarding work, leisure, marriage, family, love, and religion through a comparison with the debates and competing interpretations of these values in Japan.     Remarks: Department Board members disagreed with the suggestion that they replace the word 'understanding' with another word such as 'identity, explain, analyze or synthesize' as suggested by UGE.
syllabus: Week 1: Images of Japan This lesson introduces students to widespread popular images of Japan in Asian and Western media and academia. It considers how and why these images have changed over time and asks students to consider the usefulness and limits of generalizations about other people and societies.   Week 2: Nation, Nationalism and the Imperial System This lesson introduces students to theories explaining nationalism. It then uses these theories to consider nationalism in Japan. It explores the Japanese Imperial system in the context of historical developments in Japanese nationalism. Read:   1)   Akemi Nakamura. "Textbook Fight Not as Simple as it Seems" The Japan Times. 7 August 2005.                2)      Reiji Yoshida. "Panel Set to Ponder Female on the Throne." The Japan Times. 25 January 2005.   Week 3: The "Economic Miracle" This lesson explores two main theories behind Japan's economic development and subsequent recession of the 1990s. It considers the reasons for Japan's economic success, the experience of this success for Japanese people, and asks students to consider competing interpretations of Japan's economic development. Read: Kenneth B. Pyle, "Japan's Postwar National Purpose," chapter 3 in his The-Japanese Question: Power and Purpose in a New Era pp.20-41   Week 4: Law and Order This lesson examines changing perceptions of social order in Japan. It explores the catalysts behind these changing perceptions and considers the relationship between perceptions and reality. Students are asked to consider how Japan and their own societies maintain trust in the government, faith in social justice, and belief in the reliability of public order. Read:   1 )  Wolfgang Herbert. "Yakuza and the Law" In Harumi Befu, Tom Gill, Jeffery Eades (eds.). Globalization and Social Change in Contemporary Japan. Pp. 143-158.               2)   Michael Williams. "Revolving Door: Many Japanese Banks Ran Amok While Led by Former Regulars. Wall Street Journal (Eastern edition). Jan 19, 1996.   Week 5: Work and Workplaces This lesson introduces competing interpretations of Japan's employment strategies. It urges students to consider the reasons behind these competing interpretations. It also helps students to consider the system from the perspective of Japanese workers according to gender, age, and educational level, and encourages them to consider their own strategies and values as future members of their society's workforce. Read:   1)  Joy Hendry. "Careers and Continuity" in Understanding Japanese Society pp. 149-167               2)   Yamada, A. "Death of a Salaryman" Japan Quarterly. Jul-Sep 1999 vol. 46 (3): 40-47               3)   Mathews, Gordon. "Seeking a Career, Finding a Job: How Young People Enter and Resist the Japanese World of Work" In Gordon Mathews and Bruce White (eds.) Japan k Changing Generations: Are Young People Creating A New Society?               4)   Yuko Ogasawara. "Gossip" in Office Ladies and Salaried Men. pp. 70 - 97.   Week 6: Education This lesson introduces five theories that explain the role of education in society. Students are asked to consider how these theories may be useful in understanding Japan's educational system and philosophies. Students are encouraged to consider their own beliefs and principles regarding the purpose of education and their strategies as students-within theu educational system. Read:   1)   Joy Hendry. "The Education System" in Understanding Japanese Socieiy pp. 96-114              2)   Lee Cunin, Maria. 2004. "The Students Academic Experience: Students' Thoughts on Reform and the Future." In her Student Views in Japan: A Study of Japanese Students ' Perceptions of their First Years at University. Pp. 119-138   Week 7: Home and Family This lesson introduces several theories regarding the family in modem society. It then explores changes in Japanese family forms over time. Students are asked to articulate their own values toward love, marriage, and family in contrast to what they are learning about Japan. Read: 1) Joy Hendry. "The House and Family System" in Understanding Japanese Society pp.22-41            2) Anne Allison. "Family and Home" chapter 6 in Nightwork: Sexualify, Pleasure and Corporate Masculinity in a Tokyo Hostess Club pp. 102-113   Week 8: Women and Gender This lesson examines changes in women's and men's roles and ideals in Japanese society over time. Students are urged to reflect upon their own understandings of gender in comparison to perceptions and practices of gender common in Japan. Read:  1)  Surniko Iwao. "Myths and Realities " in The Japanese Woman: Traditional Image and Changing Reality. pp. 1-30             2)   Wiseman, Paul. USA Today. 'Wo Sex Please, We're Japanese." 2 June 2004.   Week 9: Leisure and Play This lesson explores the role of leisure in modem societies and the development of the concept and practices of leisure in modem Japan. Leisure in Japan is explored in terms of gender, age, class, and generational differences. Students are encouraged to articulate their own attitudes toward leisure in relation to work, to consider how perceptions of how leisure have changed over time in their society, and to discuss how they expect their own leisure practices will change as they age. Read: Anne Allison. "A Type of Routine." In Nightwork. P. 42-56.   Week 10: Mass Culture and Popular Culture This lesson explores the development of mass culture in Japan and explains the ways in which popular culture may serve as the basis for both social change and the reproduction of the status quo. Students are asked to consider how their own participation in popular culture and mass culture both generates changes in their societies and reproduces global capitalist structures. Read: Merry White. "The Marketing of Adolescence in Japan: Buying and Dreaming." In Lise Skov and Brian Moeran (eds.) Women, Media and Consumption in Japan. P. 255-273   Week 11: Religion This lesson explores basic religious traditions and philosophies in Japan and how the role of religion in Japan has changed over time. It considers the role of religion at the level of state politics as well as in everyday life. Theories regarding religion in modern society are introduced. Students are urged to develop their own interpretations of the role of religion in modern societies and in their own lives.  Read:   1)   Joy Hendry. "Religious Influences," Understanding Japanese Society. pp. 115-132               2)  Pfeiffer, William Sanborn. "Makihari: New Religion and Japanese Popular Culture" Journal of Popular Culture. Fall 2000 vol. 34. Iss. 2, pp. 155 – 174   Week 12: Student Presentations   Week 13: Conclusion This lesson reviews the social issues which Japanese consider to be most serious such as the emergence of diversity, subcultures, and changing youth expectations and desires regarding adulthood. It discusses, through surveys, how Japanese people view their society and how they view their future. It asks students to consider which problems are seen as the most critical in their societies, how their own societies view their future, and how popular views about their societies and about their societies' future are related to the beliefs held by individuals. Read: (Read one-quarter of letters) "Rethinking the War Experience." In Frank Gibney. (ed.) In SensG: The Japanese Remember the Pacific War Letters to the Editor of the Asahi Shimbun. pp. 283-318.

title: Japanese Popular Culture in Cultural Globalization
requirements: UGEC1271 is double-coded with JASP1160. ;Not for Japanese Studies Majors; and students who have taken JASP1110 or 1160.;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC1271 is double-coded with JASP1160.)  This course examines the development and academic significance of various forms of Japanese popular culture such as films, comics, music, TV dramas and culinary culture, from multidisciplinary perspectives, including history, cultural anthropology, cultural studies and media studies. It aims to deepen understanding the following three facets of Japanese popular culture:1) the applicaton of cultural globalization theory in Japan; 2) the global strategy of Japanese cultural industries; and 3) social and intellectual transformation of contemporary Japanese society. Using concrete examples and grounding on representative academic writings, this course discusses the globalization of Japanese popular culture and relevant issues in indigenization, glocalization, hybridization, transnational cultural flows and media-mix. Students are trained to understand the nature and cultural implications of Japanese popular culture in an Asian context. Besides lectures, discussions and readings, this course selectively utilizes topical essays (projects), e-learning, audio-visual materials and fieldwork-based assignments as supplementary teaching tools.
outcome: Through a historical and cultural analysis of different facets of Japanese popular culture, this course aims to achieve the following three academic goals:1)      It aims to use Japanese popular culture as a medium or stepping stone to enhance students’ interest in and understanding of Japanese history, society and culture.2)      It aims to deepen understanding of nature and impact of Japanese cultural industry and its cultural implications in an Asian context.3)      It aims to discuss Japanese popular culture within the theoretical framework of cultural globalization. Having taken this course, students will be equipped with a basic ability to analyse cultural phenomenon in the lens of such cultural concepts as indigenization, glocalization, hybridization, transnational cultural flows, media mix, cultural colonialism and orientalism.
syllabus: Main Objective:This main purpose of course is to examine the global popularization and localization of Japanese popular culture from historical, cultural and comparative perspectives within the theoretical framework of cultural globalization. It aims to indicate that the cultural flows between Japan and Asia are by no means one-way traffic and Asia has been interacting and collaborating with the Japanese in creating, manufacturing, marketing and distributing cultural products for decades. Lectures, discussions and readings highlight different facets of cultural acculturation and transnational interaction found in Japan-Asia cross-cultural flows, such as appropriation, hybridization, global localization business strategy, the making of localized editions, the local application of Japanese formula, joint production, and the participation of foreign artists and staff. Solidly grounding on empirical data as well as theories from cultural globalization and cross-cultural studies, this course will be a pioneering teaching and learning project to explore uncharted research territories in Japanese studies, Japan-Hong Kong relations, and cultural studies. Key Issues and Problems:The following key issues and problems regarding the globalization of Japanese popular culture in an Asian context will be addressed in this course within the theoretical fiarnework of cultural globalization: 1) The idea that the influx of Japanese cultural products is a form of cultural imperialism that aims to expand Japanese economic interest and to spread Japanese value and lifestyle in Asia will be empirically and theoretically reexamined and challenged. It shows that cultural imperialism is an outdated model in cross-cultural studies, because it fails to understand the dynamic mechanism in transnational cultural flows and cultural forces of localization and hybridization.2) While using "glocalization" (Roland Robertson uses it to refer to the localization strategy employed by multi-national companies to promote their products in different nations) to investigate the global business strategy of Japanese companies such as Sony, Nintendo, Capcom and Bandai in Asian and global markets, this course underscores the limitation of the glocalization theory in the East Asian context, as it fails to see the initiative taken by Asian artists and businessmen to creatively and selectively domesticate Japanese elements.3) This course uses Japanese popular culture as a mirror or text to decode social and cultural issues of contemporary Japan. For examples, themes about ethnicity, gender, social hierarchy, political ideology, and cultural identity will be examined in the lens of Japanese popular culture. Core Content, Structure and Selected Topics:The course content of this course investigates the three facets of Japanese popular culture: (1) the application of cultural globalization theory in Japan, (2) the global strategy of Japanese cultural industries, (3) social and intellectual transformation of contemporary Japanese society. Accordingly, its structure follows the design of core content and contains the following three parts: Part 1: Japanese Popular Culture and Cultural Globalization: Theories and PracticesSelected Topics:(a) Introduction to Basic Theories in Cultural Studies and Cultural Globalization(b) Globalization of Japanese Popular Culture in an Asian Context(c) Reexamining the Cultural Imperialism, Orientalism and Nihonjinron  Discourses(d) Indigenization and Hybridization of Japanese Popular Culture in Asia (1) Food and Fashion(e) Indigenization and Hybridization of Japanese Popular Culture in Asia (2) TV Programs Part 2: Interplay between Globalization and JapanesenessSelected Topics:(a) Nihonjinron in Japanese Movies and Alternative Mode of Globalization(b) The Formation of Japanese Manga and Anime and Their Hybridity(c) The Making of an Otaku Culture in Japan and Beyond(d) The Adaptation of Chinese Tradition in Japanese popular culture Part 3: The Global Strategy of Japanese Cultural IndustriesSelected Topics:(a) Glocalization of Japanese Video Games and Cyber Culture(b) Transnational Collaboration and Cross-cultural Themes in Japanese Movies(c) Japaneseness and Universality in Japanese Comics and Animated Series(d) Exporting and Domesticating Japanese Formula in Asian Drama and Music(e) Media-mix as a Business Strategy in Japanese Cultural Industries

title: Understanding Japanese Languages and Culture
requirements: UGEC1281 is double-coded with JASP1120. ;Not for Japanese Studies Majors; and students who have taken JASP1120. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC1281 is double-coded with JASP1120.) This course explores the relationship between Japanese language and culture. Everyday communication strategies adopted by people in Japanese society will be examined in terms of Japanese language expressions, styles and structures. Linguistic approaches will be the principal analytical tools employed in this course but interdisciplinary approaches will also be adopted. This course is designed for students who are interested in knowing more about Japan but who have very limited or no knowledge of the Japanese language. Student will gain an understanding of the basic structure of the Japanese language, learn how usage of the language reflects Japanese culture and behavior, and explore how communication patterns of Japanese speakers differ from speakers of other languages.
outcome: 1. Students are expected to have gained a basic understanding of the structure of the Japanese language and historical changes of the writing system. Moreover, students will be able to understand the usage of the language, different styles and when each should be used, and different strategies used in expressing politeness. 2. Students are expected to understand the relationship between the language expressions and the behaviors of Japanese people in various circumstances and the reasons behind such behaviors. 3. Through comparing the culture of Japan with that of Hong Kong, students will become able to make comments on the characteristics of each and distinguish between the two. 4. Students will be able to perform an elementary study regarding Japanese culture and this will help the students to develop his/her further study in Japanese Studies.
syllabus: Week 1 Lesson 1 Introduction to Japanese culture: This lesson explains how Japanese culture influences daily life in Hong Kong today. The usage and the characteristics of Japanese language will also be discussed.   Week 2 Lesson 2 Introduction to the historical changes of kanji and kana in the Japanese language: This lesson explains the historical changes of kanji and kana in Japanese language. Focus will be on why Japanese absorbed Chinese characters into their writing system and the process of how Chinese characters were converted to the modern kana (hiragana and katakana).   Week 3 – Week 4 Lesson 3 Introduction to the phrases expressing linguistic politeness: This lesson briefly explains the phrases expressing linguistic politeness. These include honorific expressions, expressions used in making requests, making apologies, expressing gratitude and personal opinions, giving advice and asking for permission. Emphasis will be placed on when and how these expressions are used. The relationship between such expressions and the characteristics of hierarchy in Japanese society will also be discussed.   Week 4 - 5 Lesson 4 Strategies used in making requests and refusals in Japanese:  This lesson discusses how Japanese make requests and refuse the requests of others. Such expressions are often used in daily life by Japanese but are not easily understood by foreigners. Special attention will be given to:  a. the difference in behaviour between Japanese and non Japanese in making requests and refusals. b. how this behaviour reflects characteristics of Japanese culture.    Week 6 – Week 7 Lesson 5 Strategies used in making apologies and taking responsibility: This lesson discusses how Japanese apologize and take responsibility after misconduct such as scandals or accidents. For example, we often see the top management of Japanese companies bow to the public to apologize for their misconduct and they may even quit the company in order to take responsibility for problems. In Hong Kong, it is rare to see such a phenomenon. We will discuss the mechanism of how Japanese make an apology and the effect of the Japanese way of apologizing upon social situations. Special attention will be given to the comparison of the styles of apology in Japanese and Hong Kong societies. We will also discuss the relationship between the Japanese way of apologizing and issues related to the Sino-Japanese War.   Week 8 – Week 9 Lesson 6 Ambiguity in the Javanese language: Compared with other languages such as Chinese, there are many ambiguous linguistic practices in Japanese. These include, for example, the deletion of the subject "watashi" (I), the use of "koto ni narimashita" (become something) rather than "koto ni shimashita" (I decided to do something) when talking about personal matters such as getting married, and the frequent use of intransitive verbs rather than transitive verbs. Most Japanese language learners including Hong Kong learners have experienced difficulties with these expressions and practices in their learning process. We will analyze and comment on this phenomenon.   Week 9 – Week 10 Lesson 7 The Business Manner of Japanese: This lesson discusses how Japanese behave in business negotiations. Japanese are often criticized for not stating their true feelings and opinions. They often use expressions such as "kangaesasetekudasai" (Please let me think about it), "kekkoo desu" (It's O.K. /No, thank you) to indirectly express their opinions. We will discuss why Japanese behave in such a way and the correct way to deal with a Japanese business partner.   Week 10 - Week 11  Lesson 8 Japanese language in a sociolinguistic perspective: In this lesson we discuss the following items of importance in sociolinguistics as they appear in the Japanese language. a. the comparison between written and colloquial styles b. the comparison of language usage for men and women c. the comparison between the standard language and dialect d. the comparison of language usage between the young and the elderly e. the comparison between formal styles and informal styles f. the comparison between jargon and standard expressions   Week 12 Lesson 9 The success and failure in learning Javanese language (with a focus on Hong Kong Cantonese speaking learners): First, we will give a brief introduction to the theories of second language acquisition. Next, the factors affecting the results of the process of second language learning will be discussed. To ensure a better understanding, case studies comparing English language acquisition among Japanese and Hong Kong people will be introduced. Finally, by summarizing the above observations and the characteristics of both Japanese and Cantonese, we will comment on the difficulties experienced by Hong Kong Cantonese speaking Japanese learners.   Week 13 Lesson 10 Special topics on Japanese 1anguage and Japanese culture:  Special topics will be selected to help students understand the relationship between Japanese language and culture. a. "shin go ryuukoogo taishoo" (New words and buzz terms Grand Prix) b. "kotoshi no kanji" (The Chinese character of this year)

title: Chinese-Japanese-Korean Movies: Appreciation and Comparison
requirements: UGEC1293 is double-coded with JASP1130. ;Not for Japanese Studies Majors; and students who have taken GESC2080, JASP1130 or 1150. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC1293 is double-coded with JASP1130.)  With the growing popularity of Asian movies in the 1990s, Japan's collaborations and interactions with its neighbors - China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Korea - have become a major research topic among scholars in the fields of film studies, cultural studies, anthropology and Asian studies. Moreover, cross-border film studies have become an important avenue of understanding globalization. It is within such context that this course aims to expose students to a global perspective for understanding movies of China (including Hong Kong and Taiwan), Japan and Korea by comparing some common themes represented in movies of these countries. This course consists of four major parts focusing on the comparative studies of Chinese, Japanese and Korean cinemas: (1) Nostalgia in Romantic Movies, (2) Historical Trauma in Violent Movies, (3) Images of Women in Women-Centered Films, and (4) Urban Images in Movies Based on Cities. These themes are chosen for their significances of reflecting the recent history of colonization or decolonization, and the experience of modernization in these East Asian societies. Through the above comparative studies, students will learn how different cultures maintain their uniqueness in an era of globalization; and how these topics have been differently interpreted and visualized by the post-war generation of each region. This course emphasizes interdisciplinary research and study methods, including film criticism, history and cultural studies. The lecturer will commence each lesson by referring to academic readings, and show film clips if necessary, to serve as the basis for in-class discussions.

title: Understanding Japanese Culture and Society Through Movies
requirements: UGEC1302 is double-coded with JASP1140. ;Not for Japanese Studies Majors; and students who have taken GESC2080, JASP1140 or 1150. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC1302 is double-coded with JASP1140.) Film is always regarded as an important medium for understanding society and culture. This course looks into the formation and characteristics of Japanese mentality and behaviour, through Japanese movies and academic readings of Japanese studies. This course consists of two major parts: 1) Lesson 2 to Lesson 7: Japanese Self-Image as Revealed in Japanese Movies; 2) Lesson 8 to Lesson 12: Comparison of the Thinking Patterns of Japan and Others. This course emphasizes interdisciplinary research and study methods, including film criticism, history and cultural studies. The lecturer will commence each lesson by referring to various academic readings, and will show movie clips if necessary, to serve as the basis for in-class discussions.
outcome: Ø     Be able to understand the Japanese mentality and behaviour.    Ø     Acquire the ability to examine and investigate the academic and cultural meanings of movies from a macroscopic – cross-border, cross-era, interdisciplinary – perspective.    Ø     Be able to extract and digest messages carried in movies, in order to obtain a more thorough understanding of the relationships between Japan and other countries, including China, Korea and America.    Ø     Acquire a more thorough understanding of the influence of Japanese culture.    Ø     Further develop their critical thinking, presentation and writing skills through interactive teaching methods such as discussions, classwork and essay writing.
syllabus: Lesson 1 Introduction (課程介紹) This lesson introduces the objectives and learning approach of this course.   Part 1 (Lesson 2 to Lesson 7) Japanese Self-Image as Revealed in Japanese Movies (從電影看日本人的自我觀) This part brings out different predominant theories on Japanese mental structure, and discusses whether they can be applied to the Japanese mentality revealed in Japanese movies produced from the post-war period to present, so as to investigate the degree of their validity.   Lesson 2 Japanese Hierarchy and Bushido (日本的階級觀念與武士道) This lesson discusses the function of hierarchy in Japanese society, and the important role of bushido in establishing the traditional Japanese ideals of conduct. Readings: Kurosawa-Film Studies and Japanese Cinema, and《武士道》   Lesson 3 Japanese Moral Standards and the Shame Culture (日本道德觀與恥的文化) This lesson compares the Japanese shame culture to the guilt culture by investigating the relationship between groupism and individualism in Japan, and sees how it shapes the Japanese moral standards. Readings: The Anatomy of Dependence, and《日本倫理思想與日本現代化》   Lesson 4 Passive Individualism Among the Youth (日本新一代的被動個人主義) This lesson examines the difference between individualism in Japanese new generation’s view of love and that of traditional thinking, and investigates the profound influences of Japanese movies and television culture on young people. Readings: The Creative Edge: Emerging Individualism in Japan“Transcending the Outsider’s Role: A Japanese Superstar in Japan and Hong Kong”, and   Lesson 5 Japan’s Return to Asia: Political Meaning Behind the Boom of Takeshi Kaneshiro (金城武熱潮的形成和意義) This lesson discusses the transformation of Japanese identification of being Asian from the Meiji Westernization to the age of globalization, by examining the political meaning behind the boom of Takeshi Kaneshiro in the 1990s. Reading: “Facing Challenges in a New Age: A Multicultural and New Generation Identity for Japan, through Kaneshiro Takeshi and Kubotsuka Yōsuke”   Lesson 6-7 A New Stage in Japan-China and Japan-Korea Relationships (對中和對韓的日本新觀) This lesson analyzes the new views on China and Korea revealed in Japanese movies produced from the 1990s to present.   Readings: Interpreting History in Sino-Japanese Relations, and 《東亞三國的近現代史》   Part 2 (Lesson 8 to Lesson 12) Comparison of the Thinking Patterns of Japan and Others (比較日本與其他民族集團的思維模式) Through the comparison between movies of Japan and other nations, this part focuses on the different thinking patterns of Japan and others.   Lesson 8 Japanese Self-Deprecation and Male Chauvinism (日本自嘲文化與男尊女卑) Through the comparison of comedies of Japan and America, this lesson investigates the unique culture of self-deprecation, and the different roles of men and women in Japan.   Readings:Beyond Common Sense: Sexuality and Gender in Contemporary Japan, and Different Games Different Rules - Why American and Japanese Misunderstand Each Other.   Lesson 9 The Logic and Influence of Amae (“依愛”的邏輯與影響) This lesson discusses how amae (dependence) affects the Japanese logical thinking and behaviour by comparing suspense movies of Japan, Hong Kong and Korea. Readings: “Higaisha-ishiki: The Psychology of Revolting Youth in Japan,”  《日本的自我：社會心理學家論  日本人》及〈《花樣奇緣》呈現的日本人精神面貌〉   Lesson 10 Imaged Masculinity and the Aesthetics of Violence (男性想像與暴力美學) This lesson investigates the meaning of ninjo (human feelings) and giri (obligation), and the relationship between Japanese yakuza culture and gangster films. It also compares the different points of view of Takeshi Kitano and Quentin Tarantino in presenting the “aesthetics of violence” and “tragic hero”. Readings: The Chrysanthemum and the Sword: Patterns of Japanese Culture, and Myth and Masculinity in the Japanese Cinema: Towards a Political Reading of the “Tragic Hero”.   Lesson 11 Self and Others: A Comparison of Japanese and American Godzillas (日美哥斯拉呈現的 “我” 與“他”) This lesson investigates the socio-political meanings of Godzilla in Japan, and looks into the different viewpoints on the concepts of “others” between Japanese and American monster films.  Readings: Hibakusha Cinema: Hiroshima, Nagashima, Nagasaki, and the Nuclear Image in Japanese Film; and “From Godzilla to Train Man: A Study of the Japanese Self Image in the Context of the West”   Lesson 12 Cinderella & Women Warrior: A Comparison of Disney and Miyazaki’s Heroines (比較日美動畫中的女性形象) This lesson investigates the Japanese national spirit revealed in animations, compares the different images of female characters in Hayao Miyazaki’s and Disney’s animations, and examines their different cultural significance. Readings: Mouse Morality: The Rhetoric of Disney Animated Film, and Anime from Akira to Princess Mononoke: Experiencing Contemporary Japanese Animation   Lesson 13 Mid-Term Report Review and Conclusion (中期報告成績討論與課程總結)         A follow-up discussion of the mid-term reports submitted by students; and a general review     of the topics, discussions and materials covered in the course, and helps students to     prepare for the final examination.

title: Perspectives in Economics
requirements: UGEC1511 is double-coded with ECON1010;Not for majors in Faculty of Business Administration; not for ECON, GLEF, QFRM Majors; and students who have taken DSME1030, 1040, ECON1010 or 2011.;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC1511 is double-coded with ECON1010.)   This is an introduction to the nature of the economic problem and how society and man deal with the economic problem. It will cover resource allocation and the concept of economic efficiency, product and factor markets, macroeconomic indicators and the nature of macroeconomic problems, and macroeconomic policy. Economic concepts and theories will be applied to various social and economic issues such as marriage, crime and government policies.
outcome: It is expected that students will:-          acquire problem solving skills to think like an economist.-          master a set of concepts that will help them think more coherently and consistently about a wide range of problems-          be able to use these skills in their everyday lives as consumers, savers, entrepreneurs, investors, workers, citizens and participants in a global economy.
syllabus: Perspectives in Economics will introduce the fundamental concepts of economic and issues in economic research, covering both micro and macro economics. The course attempts to illustrate the importance and beauty of economics via a non-technical approach, using only elementary mathematics and graphs for expositions. Topics will include concepts of rationality, opportunity cost analysis, the functioning of supply and demand, the role of government and fiscal policy, the banking system and monetary policy, pricing, and some topics pertaining to crime, marriage and international trade. title: Hong Kong Movies and Politics
requirements:
UGEC1516 is double-coded with GPAD1074. 
Not for Government and Public Administration Majors; and students who have taken GPAD1074. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC1516 is double-coded with GPAD1074.)  Movies are political; Hong Kong movies are no exception. This course will take a political-historical approach to introduce to students different political contexts (including British-colonial rule, anti-Japanese war, Cold War, and 1997 political handover) in which Hong Kong movies are produced, and the possible political readings of these movies. In the end, the course will examine whether these movies, as an art form, can transcend politics.

title: Fundamentals of Public Administration
requirements: UGEC1522 is double-coded with GPAD1030.;Not for Government and Public Administration Majors; and students who have taken GPAD1030.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC1522 is double-coded with GPAD1030.) This course introduces contemporary study and practice of public administration, and the characteristics and roles of public bureaucracy in various types of administrative systems. Students will also learn to analyze some issues such as codes of conduct for civil servants, budgetary politics and redress of administrative grievances.
outcome: After taking this course, it is expected that students will have developed the following capabilities and skills: By the end of this introductory course students should be able to develop broad sweep knowledge of a range of approaches to the study of public administration and, to a certain degree, an in-depth knowledge of selected concepts and theories. These theories were selected because of their direct relevance for developing an understanding of modern government behaviour.   Public administration is often considered in a managerial manner, as little more than control and straightforward analysis of efficiency and economy. This is not necessarily the case. People from different walks of life tend to have different expectations of government. This course is intended to foster a change in attitudes among students. After the course, students are expected to have the ability and tendency to think critically from multidisciplinary perspectives and to provide a critical appreciation of the strengths and weaknesses of any theoretical approach. Most important of all, by taking this course, students should have developed an understanding of the basic concepts and theories in public administration and should have gained the ability to apply them to the context of Hong Kong. Public administration, as an area of study, is very much a study based in American context. Therefore, it is important for students to reflect on the concepts and approaches covered in the course, and to consider how they can contribute to a better understanding of public administration in Hong Kong. The course is intended to reinforce communication skills on the part of students. Through the training in debates and discussions, students should have developed the ability to convey abstract ideas and complicated issues in a concrete and organized manner.

title: Government and Politics of China
requirements: UGEC1540 is double-coded with GPAD1070. ;Not for Government and Public Administration Majors; and students who have taken GPAD1070.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC1540 is double-coded with GPAD1070.)  This is an introductory course that surveys key issues in Chinese politics, including the historical background of the system, the roles of the party/state, the style of leadership, the forms of popular participation, and the distinctive features of Chinese politics. The focus of this course is political change. Classic essays by Sun Yatsen, Lu Xun, Mao Zedong and others provide students with grounding in the key problems modern China has faced, as well as the solutions it has pioneered. From that foundation, we will move on to contemporary institutions and intellectual debates over inequality, human rights, and the future shape of political reform in China.
outcome: By successfully completing this course, you should be able to - Acquire a knowledge and understanding of the Chinese political history and contemporary politics of China - Explore the main theoretical, empirical, and methodological approaches to the study of Chinese politics; - Relate these approaches to the broader field of comparative politics; - Develop conceptual ability to analyze and explain major issues and challenges confronting China today.

title: Globalization of Korean Popular Culture
requirements: Not for Global Studies (GLBS and GLSD) Majors; and students who have taken GLBS3202 or 3402.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: This course is designed to introduce students to contemporary Korean popular culture, and more specifically the 21st century South Korean cultural phenomenon called Hallyu (Korean wave) – its promises and limitations as well as its popularity and backlash against it. By taking an interdisciplinary approach to the topic, we will study food, film, television, music, fashion and sports and ask how they participate in the transnational production, distribution and circulation of culture, identity, modernity, tradition, ideology and politics both regionally and globally. One of the major questions this course will explore is the curious ways in which these popular media continuously re-stage and re-define Korea’s historical past in order to comment on its present. This course also targets to equip students with analytical tools to critically think about popular culture as well as understand theories of cultural globalization.
outcome: To identify the historical developments and current content trends of the Korean wave.    To analyze the causes and outcomes of the Korean wave.    To recognize the importance of critical thinking skills for analyzing the transnational media content and effects in a global, cultural context.

title: Understanding Global Issues from Movies
requirements: Not for Global Studies (GLBS and GLSD) Majors; and students who have taken GLBS3301.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: This course aims to introduce students to an array of global issues by using popular movies as major teaching instruments. In class, students will learn basic theories of globalization, development of global history since 1945, the contemporary structure of global order, and challenges/opportunities in the realm of global security (e.g. terrorism), global economy (e.g. free trade and inequality), global politics (e.g. global governance). The selected movie texts in this course would serve two purposes: learning tools and learning objects. On the one hand, students will analyze the features and real-life impacts of global issues depicted from these movies. On the other hand, they will also be trained to exercise critical thoughts towards the narratives conveyed from these movies. This course is suitable for students who have no prior knowledge in International Relations or Global Studies.
outcome: - Recognize the most prominent global issues in recent years - Discuss and examine features and impacts of different global issues - Diagnose the causes and backgrounds of different global issues - Apply different theories and perspectives of Globalization to the analysis of different global issues - Review and critique the narratives about certain aspects of Globalization which are embedded in the selected movie texts - Think critically

title: Understanding North Korea
requirements: Not for Global Studies (GLBS and GLSD) Majors;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: The Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK), also known as North Korea, remains as one of the most isolated and the only few nations in our world still upholding socialist ideology. For the last decades, although North Korea is a frequent issue that is widely reported in the headlines of our international media, the understanding of the nation is often mis-interpreted, ill-informed and largely distracted by insufficient information.Therefore, this course intends to go beyond the media images and messages to analyze multidisciplinary issues including the politics, economy, society and culture in North Korea. It will cover history and political ideologies in North Korea, North Korean economic reform and the development of underground economy, policy of nuclear brinkmanship, controversial issues of human rights violations, North Korean defectors and the inter-Korean relations, art and propaganda in North Korea, North Korea travel and tourism development, and also sports and nationalism in North Korea.
outcome: Course Objectives: ·       Student will learn theory of military dictatorship regime, mad-man theory and theory of nuclear proliferation. The perspective taken is that it is not irrational in terms of the regime behavior. ·       Students will study North Korean economic phenomena, including reform and restructuring, currency crisis, imposed sanction, food and foreign aids and energy production. ·       Through examination of the contemporary culture found in the North Korea, students will better understand the ideas of the propaganda art related to the socialist nation. Learning Outcomes: ·       To acquaint students with knowledge on military dictatorships and apply the theories into the real situation in North Korea. ·       Students will analyze the North Korean economic systems, also be expected to evaluate whether the economic reform in North Korea is sufficient to transform the economy or not. ·      Students will comprehend the ideas of the propaganda art and to create their own judgement on the differences between political art and pure art.

title: Basic Banking and Finance
requirements: UGEC1560 is double-coded with ECON1420. ;Not for majors in Faculty of Business Administration; not for ECON, GLEF, QFRM Majors; and students who have taken ECON1420, 3410, 3420, 3520 or GESC2410.;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC1560 is double-coded with ECON1420.)   This course is an overview of the institutional and practical aspects of the banking and financial sectors of the economy, with emphasis on how the two sectors impact on the economic well being of workers, consumers, and investors. This course is designed for students with no previous knowledge or training in economics. Topics to be discussed include: interest rate determination, operation and management of the banking system, banking policy and supervision, interbank market and liquidity, money supply, exchange rate systems and linked exchange rate, investment returns, risk diversification and portfolio choice, stock market movement, initial public offering and derivatives, financial ethics, international debt crisis, and their relationships with consumer prices, trade, investment, unemployment and the level of economic activity.
outcome: Understand the basic operation of the banking system and financial markets and the importance of ethics and integrity.  Apply and interpret the basics of asset price valuation and method to financial instruments such as equity, debt, and derivatives.  Apply relevant concepts, tools, and techniques to analyze some major financial and banking activities and issues and to understand their impacts of on people’s livelihood.  Improve ability to interpret financial data.    了解銀行體系和金融市場的基本運作及誠信和道德操守之重要。  運用和解釋股票、債券、衍生金融工具等證券資產價格評價和證券估值技巧。  運用相關概念，工具和技巧來分析一些重大的金融及銀行活動和議題，及了解其對人民生活的影響。  提高閱讀和理解財務數據資料的能力。

title: Marriage, Family and Kinship
requirements:
UGEC1625 is double-coded with ANTH1310.
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH1310. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC1625 is double-coded with ANTH1310.) This course invites students to explore the issue of gender cross-culturally through the framework of kinship. It introduces basic concepts and major issues in the areas where the study of gender and the study of kinship intersect through an anthropological lens. Issues to be explored include kinship structures and related gender roles in cross-cultural perspective, the changing relationship between marriage and love, and the various new ways of people “doing” kinship in contemporary societies and the emerging social problems resulted from these changes. Themes such as kinship and the new reproductive technologies, fictive kinship and human-pet bond will all be discussed.
outcome: • Be familiar with the basic concepts, theories and contemporary social issues relating to gender and kinship. • To gain appreciation of the culturally diverse forms and understanding of gender, marriage, family and kinship. • Be able to identify and summarize key points and arguments in scholarly anthropological writings. • To understand the practice of kinship as a means to ensure survival and establish meaningful social relations. • To think analytically about the complex linkages between individuals and society in understanding and performing various forms of intimate relationships.
syllabus: This course introduces basic concepts and major issues in the areas where the study of kinship and the study of gender intersect through an anthropological lens. Issues to be explored include kinship structures and related gender roles in cross-cultural perspective, the changing relationship between marriage and love, and the various new ways of people “doing” kinship in contemporary societies and the emerging social problems resulted from these changes. Themes such as kinship and the new reproductive technologies, fictive kinship and human-pet bond will all be discussed. Overall, the course encourages reflection on the origin and nature of human social relations by elucidating the complex linkages between individuals and society in understanding and performing various forms of kinship.   PART I: BASIC CONCEPTS OF FAMILY AND KINSHIP   1. Introduction: Concepts, Abbreviations and Symbols Issues to be discussed: What is Kinship? WHY do we study kinship, family and marriage? Kinship, family and marriage in modernity.   2. Unilineal (Patrilines and Matrilineal) and Cognatic Descent Issues to be discussed: Why is virginity so valued in patrilineal and cognatic descent groups? Do women have more power in matrilineal societies?   PART II: Kinship, Marriage, and Family Related Issues   3. Choice of Mate, Courtship and Romance before Marriage Issues to be discussed: What is romantic love and how has the notion changed over time? With whom one falls in love? What are the other factors that people consider when choosing a marital partner? How has the technological development changed how people love?   4. The “Big Day” and Romance after Marriage Issues to be discussed: What is Marriage? Why is it nearly universal? How many people can you marry? With whom? By whom? The changing wedding rites and their meanings; Globalization and International Marriages.   5. Kinship, Social Relations, and Economy Issues to be discussed: How do various practices of kinship function as means to ensure economic survival and enhancement?   6. Gender, Power and Family Issues to be discussed: What is family? Why is it important? What are the mainly types of family and how are they related to particular social structures? How do family members bond together? What are the expected gender roles of wives and husbands in modern societies across the world? Gender and power dynamics within family.   7. Childhood, Parenthood and Social Reproduction Issues to be discussed: What are the changing roles of and expectations for children? What are the roles and practices of parents in different societies in terms of childrearing and social reproduction? How are the experiences and meanings of childhood and parenthood influenced by globalization?   8. Marriage “Troubles”: Incest, Extra Marital Sex, Divorce and Remarriage Issues to be discussed: Why the incest taboo? Are we really facing marital “crises” today?   9. Adoption, Fictive Kinship and Network of Care Issues to be discussed: Why adoption? Why and how do we create fictive kinship? What are the potential challenges? Is fictive kinship fictive?   10. New Reproductive Technologies and Kinship Issues to be discussed: Reproduction and conjugal relationships; Infertility and NRTs; Do NRTs give more power and freedom to woman?   11. Homosexuality and Kinship Issues to be discussed: Consider homosexuality cross-culturally; Is homosexuality “abnormal”? Homosexuality, social discriminations and various strategies to “cope”.   12. The Elderly, Caregiving and Haven in a Heartless World Issues to be discussed: What are the social implications of an aging society? What is the comparative power of children, young adults, and the elderly within different societies? New Challenges faced by modern families in aging societies.   13. Conclusion: Biology, Culture and Kinship Issues to be discussed: Course wrap-up; Underlining the complex linkages between individuals and society in understanding and performing various forms of intimate relationships.

title: Understanding Archaeology
requirements: UGEC1633 is double-coded with ANTH1710. ;Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH1710. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC1633 is double-coded with ANTH1710.) This course aims to provide students with some basic understanding of archaeology. It will introduce the basic theory, method and practice of archaeology. It will focus on the nature and development of archaeology, data acquisition (archaeological surveys and excavations), data processing and analysis, synthesis and interpretation (reconstruction of the past environmental ecology, economic, social and cultural life) and important archaeological discoveries and studies around the world. The significance of archaeology to contemporary societies will also be discussed.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to:              Have a basic understanding of what archaeology is about.              Know the basic archaeological research methods and field methods.              Obtain basic knowledge on the developments of humans and cultures, the dynamics between nature, human and cultures, and what can we learn from the past experiences.              Appreciate the diversity and achievements of human societies and cultures.              Know how archaeology is relevant to modern societies.              Cultivate the ability of inter-disciplinary thinking, critical thinking, and the ability to conduct holistic analysis.              Have broadened the academic and intellectual horizon, and acquired new information/knowledge.
syllabus: Major contents of this course are as follows              What really is archaeology? Objectives of archaeology as a scientific discipline vs. 'archaeology' created by Hollywood movies.              How did archaeology occur? -A brief history of modern archaeology.               What are the tasks of archaeologists? -Basic principles and research approaches of archaeology              Some very significant archaeological discoveries in the world, which have shaped our knowledge today.              Academic dynamics of archaeology and sciences, and archaeology and social sciences.              The meaning of archaeological remains and research in contemporary societies: how archaeological works are relevant to us?              Archaeology in the 21st century: achievements, new objectives, challenges, and the use and abuse of archaeology in the world.

description: (UGEC1670 is double-coded with GPAD1015.) This course tries to explore the theoretical and practical links between politics and the media. It will examine the interplay of the media, the general public and the governing process in modern liberal democracy, and see how the media shape and are shaped by the other two components. title: Drugs and Culture
requirements: Not for Anthropology Majors. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: Many drugs have mind-altering effects but some are defined as legal and some as illegal. The War on Drugs have been launched in many societies but none of them has successfully become a drug-free society. This course provides students an understanding of drug-related issues from a perspective of medical anthropology. Through close readings of ethnographies, viewing of videos, and fieldtrips, the class explores drug use, prevention, and treatment in both scientific and cultural perspectives and re-examines the linkages between legal and illegal behaviours, healthy and unhealthy bodily conditions, as well as science and culture.
outcome: Students taking this course will:  acquire basic knowledge in medical anthropology;  learn the skills to comprehend the drug history in Hong Kong, China, and other parts of the world;  develop the ability to apply the learned knowledge to analyze the complex relationship between science and culture; and  acquire a critical mind to evaluate any social issues.
syllabus: The major concepts in this course include drug addiction, harm reduction, and medical anthropology. The core content includes: Module 1: What is Drug? Chapter 1&2 Introduction to Drugs The first two chapters discuss the physiological and psychological effects of mind-altering substances and their use from “traditional” societies to modern societies. Module 2: Drug Effects Chapter 3&4 Addictive Drugs: Alcohol and Heroin These two chapters introduce two highly addictive drugs, namely alcohol and heroin. We discuss their cultural consumption and harmful effects and how institutional mechanisms in different societies regulate these drugs. Chapter 5&6 Psychoactive Drugs: Marijuana and LSD These two chapters discuss the controversy over drug legalization, particularly marijuana and LSD. We discuss the effects of these drugs and whether their medical and/or recreational use should be legalized. Module 3: Drug Prevention and Treatment Chapter 7&8 Drug Scene in Hong Kong and China These two chapters discuss the changing drug use patterns in Hong Kong and China and examine how these changes are interweaved with an array of social factors, such as migration and economic development. Chapter 9&10 The War on Drugs vs. Harm Reduction These two chapters introduce the common two approaches to handling drug use issues in a society: zero tolerance and harm reduction. We discuss the effectiveness of these two approaches. Chapter 11&12 Health Consequences of Drug Taking These two chapters discuss the associated risks of drug taking, including HIV/AIDS and HCV contraction. We also discuss the effectiveness of the treatment of these drug-related diseases. Various topics in relation to drugs and culture, such as cocaine use, club drug use, ketamine use, misuse of prescription drugs, and use of new pharmaceutical products, such as Prozac and Viagra, are the selected topics for this course.

title: Data Science and Public Policy
requirements:
UGEC1731 is double-coded with DSPS1002. 
Not for Data Science and Policy Studies Majors; and students who have taken DSPS1002.
Co-requisite: Courses with course code prefix as "UGFH" or "UGFN"
description: (UGEC1731 is double-coded with DSPS1002.) This course focuses on the important connection between data science and public policy by identifying and analyzing the policy challenges posed by data science technologies. It assesses what policy options and tools are available to address them and examines what new capacities governments and also citizens must develop in the era of data science. Students would also be introduced to the professional and ethical responsibilities and social, economic, political and legal impacts under the changes and innovations brought by data science.
outcome: This course is expected to achieve the following outcomes for the students:    Good knowledge of the fundamental concepts, major intellectual and competing perspectives in the study of data science and policy studies  Awareness of the importance of the role of data science in society, including its opportunities and threats  Appreciation of the competing perspectives and contrasting views from major stakeholders on issues and problems of data science and policy studies and realization of the assumptions behind  Ability to think critically and analytically on public issues and policy challenges related to data science  Ability to apply the concepts and theories learnt in the course to formulate solutions to address real-world problems at a policymaking level
syllabus: Topics to be covered included:   Introduction and Overview: Technology and Public Policy - Normative Policymaking vs. Positive Policymaking   Part I: Theoretical Foundation and Analytical Framework   This section would define data science, which is an interdisciplinary field that uses scientific and statistical methods, processes, algorithms, and systems including big data and advanced computer technologies such as AI and IoT (Internet of Things) to generate knowledge and insights from data, and provides the theoretical framework for understanding and evaluating its impacts on policymaking.   The Rise of Data Science and Disruptive Technology   Evidence-Based Policymaking   Programme Implementation and Diffusion of Technology                               Part II: Technology and Policy Challenges   This section introduces the major inventions and trends in data science such as Big Data, which is dataset that cannot be stored, captured, managed and analyzed by means of conventional database software, and examines their impacts and implications on policymaking. In addition, the challenges of other discoveries such as open data, open innovation, and AI, for government and society would also be examined.   Big Data and Policymaking   Open Data and Open Innovation                                      AI and the Future of Work   Data Science and State Surveillance   Part III: Technology and Societal Impact   This section would discuss how data connectivity enabled by information and communication technologies (ICT) affects social and political lives. For example, smart city is a city that uses ICT to increase operational efficiency, share information with the public and improve both the quality of government services and citizen welfare. We would identify the issues and factors dividing the success and failure in the adoption and effects of those technologies.    Smart City   Social Media and Society   Social Media and Governance   Design Thinking and Public Participation

title: Introduction to Policy Studies
requirements:
Not for Data Science and Policy Studies Majors; and students who have taken DSPS1001, GPAD1030 or UGEC1522.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: This course introduces key concepts, theories and models in the study of policy sciences. To resolve complex and multi-level public problems of a globalized world in ways that help to identify and enhance the common interest, policy sciences provide an integrated and interdisciplinary approach for making good policy decisions. This course also aims to help students understand the process and structure in designing policies. The concerns of this course are integrating theory and practice into actionable social knowledge and apply it to real world problems.
outcome: By the end of this course, students should be able to:  Appreciate various fundamental concepts and different views in policy sciences and the importance of studying the subject;  Understand different theoretical approaches to policy sciences and policy studies;  Apply theories in practice to systematically analyse current political and socio-economic phenomenons;  Critically evaluate the current methodologies and approaches to policy studies;  Embark on research projects of your own to formulate actionable social knowledge to solve real world problems.
syllabus: Part I: Policy Science, Public Administration, and Political Science   1. Introduction: Situating Policy Science in the Fields This week will discuss the relationships between the three fields of policy science, public administration, and political science, and the importance of studying policy science to formulate actionable social knowledge to solve real-world problems.   2. The State and the Government This week will discuss the fundamental concepts of the state and the government, and the functions and power of the different branches of government.    3. Constitutionalism and the Rule of Law This week will discuss the concepts of constitutionalism and the rule of law, and why they are important to the protection of human rights.     4. The Emergence of Bureaucracy in Modern Society This week will discuss the emergence and evolution of bureaucracy in modern society and the main features of the bureaucratic system.   5. Challenges to the Traditional Model of Bureaucracy This week will critically evaluate the traditional model of bureaucracy and discuss the imperatives of reform since the early 1980s.   6. Public Management Theory This week will discuss the theory and content of public management and compare it with the traditional model of public administration.     7. Dimensions of Good Governance in the Public Sector This week will discuss the importance of having good governance in running the public sector and the indicators of good governance as proposed by the United Nations and World Bank.   8. The Evolution of Governance Mode As a summary of the first part of the course, this week will discuss how the transition from the traditional model of bureaucracy to NPM and further to collaborative governance recently have transformed the role of the government.    Part II: Policy Studies and the Policy Cycle   9. The Policy Cycle and Agenda-setting Using the policy cycle as the framework, the second part of the course will explain the process of policy-making. This week will focus on the first step, namely, agenda-setting, which describes how a social issue catches the attention of decision-makers.   10. Decision-making and Policy Formulation This week will focus on the second step in the policy cycle, namely, policy formulation. It will discuss how policy decisions are made according to different theories such as rationality, bounded rationality and incrementalism, and examine how different actors interact in formulating policies.    11. Policy Implementation and Policy Evaluation  This week will focus on the third and fourth steps in the policy cycle, namely, policy implementation and policy evaluation. It will discuss the key obstacles to policy implementation and the role of street-level bureaucracies. It will also discuss the different criteria, methodologies, and approaches to evaluating public policies.

title: Politics, Law and Society
requirements: UGEC1814 is double-coded with GPAD1100. ;Not for Government and Public Administration Majors; and students who have taken GPAD1100.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC1814 is double-coded with GPAD1100.) This course aims to provide an introductory examination of legal systems and the role of law in the shifting social and political contexts. Interdisciplinary perspectives (e.g. philosophical, political and sociological etc.) will be taken on to deal with the conceptual and empirical issues. The course is not designed for professional legal training, but aims to assist students to reflect on the legal phenomena they experience in their daily life.
outcome: On knowledge and comprehension level Students are expected to recognize and have basic understanding on a broad conceptual vocabulary and analytical approaches in legal discussion.   On application level Students are expected to command writing skills to convey legal and political concepts and analysis.   Students are expected to command presentation skills to convey legal political concepts and analysis.   Students are expected to identify and recognize legal issues in the shifting social and political contexts, through the lens of the legal conceptual vocabularies and analytical approaches.   On analysis level Students are expected to be able to analyze different perspectives, values and theories in relation to the controversial legal issues.   On synthesis level From the interdisciplinary perspectives and intellectual horizons the course provides, students are expected to develop critical analytical skills, so that their self-expression and communication with other people will be improved.   On evaluation level Students are expected to formulate one’s own view in understanding the legal issues, and the basic jurisprudential debates about the nature of law behind them

title: Current Hong Kong Economic Issues
requirements: UGEC1825 is double-coded with ECON1310. ;Not for Economics; Global Economics and Finance (GLEF) Majors; and students who have taken ECON1310, 2311 or 3380. ;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC1825 is double-coded with ECON1310.)  This course introduces students with no economics background to various aspects of the Hong Kong economy, such as trade, industries, logistics, housing and real estate, banking and finance, the monetary system and linked exchange rate, public finance, employment, inflation, income distribution and the China-Hong Kong economic relationship. Well-known experts from the financial sector and governmental organizations will be invited to analyse the latest information and discuss some of the above economic issues and development.
outcome: 1.      Have a sense of the development of Hong Kong economy. 2.      Understand important economic concepts and their application to analyse major economic issues and policies. 3.      Critically evaluate selected Hong Kong economic problems. 4.      Improve ability to interpret Hong Kong economic data.      1.      具備對香港經濟發展的觸覺。 2.      理解及應用重要經濟概念來分析其重大經濟議題和政策。 3.      深入評論特定的香港經濟問題。 4.      提升解讀香港經濟數據的能力。
syllabus: Hong Kong Development - Composition of GDP/GNP and price indexes, Economic performance, real estate market, the post-1997 slowdown, structural changes and recent development.  The International Transactions - The overall international balance of payments (BOP) account, Hong Kong’s BOP positions, development of transport and logistics.  Price Adjustment and Labour Employment - Labour productivity, cyclical and structural unemployment.  The Public Finance Setting - The basic taxation principles and budgetary policy stance, economic efficiency and income disparity  Banking and Finance - Hong Kong monetary system, the monetary rule of the linked exchange rate (LER), the role of Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), the importance of  international financial centre.  Integration with the Mainland – CEPA.           香港的發展 - 國內生產總值 / 國民生產總值和物價指數的構成，經濟表現，房地產市場，九七回歸後之經濟放緩，經濟結構轉型及最新發展。  國際貿易 - 整體國際收支平衡帳戶，香港的國際收支狀況，運輸物流的發展。  價格調整和勞工就業 - 勞動生產力，週期性和結構性失業。  公共財政的背景 - 稅務基本原則和財政預算政策的立場，經濟效率和所得分配差距。  銀行與金融 - 香港貨幣制度，聯繫匯率的運作準則，香港金融管理局的角色，國際金融中心之重要性。  香港與內地經濟融合 - 《內地與香港更緊密經貿關係安排》。
