title: Sports and Culture
requirements: UGEC2664 is double-coded with ANTH2390. ;Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2390.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2664 is double-coded with ANTH2390.)This course will examine the role and importance of sports in different societies and cultures, in the present and the past. Sports are often thought of as trivial, or as unimportant games to amuse young people. But in the wealthiest countries, sports represent huge portions of GDP and are important topics of daily conversation. Almost half the world watched the 2010 football/soccer World Cup. Sports have been compared to religions in their ability to unite people and to inspire fanatical devotion.The academic study of sports is interdisciplinary, with contributions from psychologists, historians, gender studies scholars, sociologists and anthropologists. This course will take an interdisciplinary approach while emphasizing anthropology’s focus on culture, on the experience of participants, and on both symbolic and political-economy aspects of sports. Topics will include Race and Performance, Sports and Rituals, Sports as Moral Education, Gender and Sexuality in Sport, Sports and Nationalism, Globalization of Sport, the Olympics, and Sports Stars and the Media. Students will be expected to do a research project for the course.
outcome: Students who have taken this course will:  be able to see and understand the cultural and historical nature of sports;  understand the roles that sports play in modern societies;  know how to apply fieldwork methods to research a group’s sub-culture, including implicit and explicit rules;  be able to analyze the elements of competition, cooperation, luck and skill, and other variables that make sports entertaining to play and watch and talk about; be able to analyze and appreciate other sports that they will encounter later in life.

title: Social Media and Culture
requirements: UGEC2665 is double-coded with ANTH2540. ;Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2540. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2665 is double-coded with ANTH2540.) This course addresses the ways in which social media and other related interactions in cyberspace have become a central element in the everyday lives of humans across the globe in the 21st Century. Our modern lives are now largely interwoven with digital technologies that have not only changed our own cultures, but also have brought forth new cultural forms through mobile phone technologies, networked “smart”-products, and cultural groupings only possible through digital means. The course approaches the anthropology of these digital cultures through its main themes—the transformation and expansion of social media, social research online, the intermixing of our online and offline lives, critical social issues of online lives, and the question of posthumanism. These themes are addressed explicitly in the course, and are also the subtexts of the different lectures, readings, and project work. Students will learn the techniques of online fieldwork and referencing. They will explore a diverse array of new ethnographies on social media: on gender, political movements, online dating, hacking, and gaming culture. These ethnographies also serve to model online social research and provide examples of methodology and design. The social consequences of cyberspace are addressed in the topics of internet pornography, addiction, surveillance, activism, and social networking. Gender and identity issues are a continuous theme throughout the course, highlighting how online lives accentuate already existing dynamics. Hong Kong connections to these subjects will also be critically discussed, often drawing on topical themes presented on blogs and forums. Students will learn of the philosophical questions of posthumanism and the nature of technologically mediated human culture. This serves as a philosophical ballast to the course allowing students to reflect personally on their own experiences and how technology has and will continue to shape their lives. The role of anthropology in understanding and capturing human culture in this context anchors on the investigation of how technology is possibly making us ‘more’ human than previous forms of cultural life.
outcome: After taking this course students will have learnt how to design and perform online fieldwork and manage digital referencing.    Students will know of and understand the recent history and development of the internet and key platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, eBay, iTunes, and the ways in which cyberspace has become embedded in the everyday work and social lives of over 2.4 billion internet users.    Students will be able to explain and discuss the various debates on the social consequences of online technologies with regard to the tensions between online lives and (so called) real lives, or digital dualism.    Students will be able to address and articulate issues of political and philosophical change, activism, addiction, surveillance, the body and visual culture in connection to mobile technologies.    Students will know of some philosophical discussions on the nature of humanity in this new epoch. The question of humanity, posthuman futures, and transhumanism is a key concern that runs throughout the course. Students will also come to consider social media and our changing digital cultures as deeply significant to new understandings of gender and body identity.
syllabus: Core Content   Online Field Work – Exploring how researchers have performed social research online. This will equip students with a knowledge of the approaches, techniques and challenges of field work in cyberspace. Whilst being a core topic, this is also part of the weekly project work of the course. Students will start   their digital research from the beginning of the course, by first developing a blog and networking with classmates.  Cultural History of Cyberspace – How did the world go online? This topic addresses the historical and technological developments that led the world to go online. Its key concern is to highlight how this has altered and affected society, and how quickly online life has become a part of everyday life.  Social Networking Sites – The rise of web 2.0 and how the internet has become social. How have different SNS emerged, how do they connect, isolate, liberate, and limit social activity? Online Culture is explored via the different uses of various SNS platforms, and their own identities.  Sex and Body Culture in Cyberspace – Tackles the social consequences of online pornography in different social and cultural circumstances. Body politics, risk, and sexuality online.  Posthumanism – This is framed in the first week as a key issue and returns as the focus of the last 2 weeks of the course.This topic looks at the impact of cyberspace on our philosophical understanding of our bodies and ourselves. How is technology changing our attitudes to gender, ethnicity, religion, and is it making us more or less human?  Online Activism – Explores the relationship between cyberspace and participatory politics, social justice, terror, and extremist groups Proposed weekly topics with core content highlighted.  Week 1:- Introduction: Starting Digital Research (Going Viral) Week 2:- Cultural History of Cyberspace Week 3:- Social Networking Sites Week 4:- Sex and Body Culture in Cyberspace Week 5:- Video Gaming Culture – Play & Recreation Week 6 :- Internet Addiction Week 7:- Online Activism Week 8:- Cyber-Surveillance and Crime Week 9:- Online Field Work Week 10:- Free Software, Inclusion, and Sharing Week 11:- Virtual, Real, and Hybrid Space Week 12:- The Selfie, the Self and Posthumanism Week 13:- Future Scenarios of Cyberspace Thematics: Online Research is covered as part of project work throughout the course. Weekly work on blogs relate to class discussions and require students to source and reference. It is addressed as a key topic in Week 1 & Week 9. Social Consequences of online lives as a theme is most strongly represented in the topics of week 5, 6, 8, 10 and 11. As well, because of the salience of this topic it  relates to other core topics such as 3,4,7, 11, and 12. Posthumanism is a philosophical theme that is introduced in Week 1 and is relevant throughout the course. It is tackled directly as a concluding theme in the final two weeks of the course (12 and 13).

title: Culture and Mind
requirements: UGEC2667 is double-coded with ANTH2320. ;Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2320. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2667 is double-coded with ANTH2320.) How can we understand the minds of other people? Do people in different cultures or societies feel and think in different ways? How do childhood experiences affect people and shape or even determine what kinds of persons they will become? What is it like to be mentally abnormal or even pathological? Do people in different cultures or societies experience, understand, and treat psychopathology in different ways? This course examines psychological experiences—feelings, perceptions, thoughts, and motivations—from social and cross-cultural perspectives. It sets out to explore the intersection between anthropology, a field that typically turns to the exotic other, and psychology, a field that often takes the universality of mental activities and mechanisms for granted. Specific focus is placed upon how ethnographers, clinicians, and researchers with training in both fields grapple with various mental phenomena and different ways of understanding them. As most of the materials are drawn from psychological anthropology, this course also serves as an eclectic introduction to this subfield, which was once influential in the history of American anthropology.
outcome: 1.        Students will acquire solid knowledge of cross-cultural comparisons of psychological experiences and their understandings.   2.        Students will gain comprehension of the key debates about the universality and relativity of human emotions and individual behavior.   3.        Students will think more critically, and develop practical skills and knowledge, about how to understand the minds of other people who are either from the same culture or society or not.   4.        Students will achieve comprehension of the major ideas in psychological anthropology, the development in this field and the relationship of psychological anthropology to the general discipline of cultural anthropology.
syllabus: This course introduces students to the studies of psychological experiences from social and cross-cultural perspectives. It examines the intersection between anthropology and psychology, with a specific focus on how ethnographers, clinicians, and researchers with training in both fields grapple with various mental phenomena and different ways of understanding them.   Week 1. Introduction   The course is divided into three parts. The first part “Depth Psychology and Its Cultural Formulations” begins with the Freudian psychoanalysis and its discovery of the unconscious, which has almost become the hallmark of the modern mind. This is followed by a discussion on the encounter of psychoanalysis with 19th-century anthropology that has resulted in imaginative meditations on culture and civilization.   Week 2. The Discovery of the Unconscious   Week 3. Is Oedipus Complex Universal?   Week 4. Culture as Collective Neurosis   Week 5. Civilization and Its Effects   The second part “Culture and Personality and Beyond” deals with some of the most serious endeavors to explore the minds of non-western cultures and societies from the side of anthropology, with a particular focus on the “culture and personality” school that once dominated American anthropology in the middle of the 20th century. The most important strands of studies that derived from it, including comparative childhood studies, phenomenology, and ethnopsychology, are also introduced here.   Week 6. From Configurations to National Characters   Week 7. Cultural and Personality with a Psychoanalytic Bent   Week 8. Comparative Childhood Studies   Week 9. Phenomenology and Ethno-psychology   The last part of the course “The Abnormal Mind” shifts the focus to psychopathology. It begins with culture-bound syndromes that once flourished in the literature of transcultural psychiatry, followed by an extended discussion on the psychotic condition—a fundamental human mental process—and its institutional treatment, and ends with the latest efforts in anthropology to explore the individual mind in society.   Week 10. Culture-Bound Syndromes   Week 11. The Psychotic Mind   Week 12. The Asylum   Week 13. Explorations of Subjectivity

title: Hong Kong Education Policy and Society
requirements: Not for students majoring in programmes offered by Faculty of Education; not for CLED and ELED Majors. Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: This course aims to discuss and facilitate students to reflect education issues, policies and practices in Hong Kong. By applying sociological and political concepts and theories, the course will critically analyze current education issues and its development. This course will help students to understand and reflect on the interplay between politics, society and education system and its effect. It aims at equip students with a broader and deeper understanding of Hong Kong education policies and education system.
outcome: This course aims to equip students with knowledge and skills to assist them to review and reflect on education issues in Hong Kong. Student are expected to achieve the following objectives:  To know the basic and evolving concepts, theories, policies and issues related to Hong Kong education  To understand the development of Hong Kong education system and its socio-political context  To analyse education phenomenon and policies with sociological and political perspectives  To evaluate and appreciate the cultures and values in educational improvement.

title: Interpersonal Violence
requirements: UGEC2680 is double-coded with SOWK2200. ;Not for Social Work Majors; and students who have taken SOWK2200.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2680 is double-coded with SOWK2200.) The purposes of this course are to provide students a basic understanding of violence that takes place in our daily life in the contexts of intimate relationship, family, school and community and to arouse their consciousness of contemporary values of equality, human rights and social justice. Various concepts and theories of violence will be introduced to explore the nature, causes, consequences and trends of violence in different aspects of life. Emphasis will be placed on the issues of interpersonal violence in contemporary societies. Social policy and provisions to prevent and eliminate interpersonal violence will also be discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:1.      Critically examine the contemporary perspectives, concepts and theories on interpersonal violence.2.    Analyze causes and consequences of interpersonal violence in different contexts.3.      Apply and integrate interdisciplinary theories of violence to evaluate current policy and strategies on tackling violence.4.      Reflect on ways to combat violence and help to promote a peaceful environment.5.      Appreciate the contemporary values of equality, human rights and social justice.
syllabus: 1.      Common misunderstanding and myths of interpersonal violence.2.      Contemporary perspectives and theories of violence from anthropology, education, medical science, politics, psychology, sociology and social work.3.      Nature, causes, consequences and trends of interpersonal violence.4.      The needs of victims and perpetrators of interpersonal violence.5.      Risk and protective factors of violence at personal, family, school, community and policy levels.6.      Issues of violence in regard to different genders, ages, classes, sexual orientations and cultures.7.      Current social policy and prevention programs on interpersonal violence.

title: Globalization and Politics
requirements: UGEC2683 is double-coded with GPAD2355.;Not for Government and Public Administration Majors; and students who have taken GLSD2301, GPAD2355 or UGEC2352.;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2683 is double-coded with GPAD2355.) This course introduces undergraduate students to the key concepts, theoretical frameworks, and main political discussions/reflections related to globalization. Globalization itself is introduced in a broad sense not limited by the economic aspect but a common experience of social change. For example, global environmental challenges, the common threat of nuclear crisis, the controversy between sovereignty and human rights, and the North-South divide. With both the historical and thematic perspectives, the class engages students with most recent research and debate on the topic. On the one hand, the class encourages students to relate their own experiences and observations in their own societies to digest what globalization is and what its impacts are. On the other hand, it also leads them to reflect on politics and social development in their own societies, in the context of globalization.
outcome: Understand the main concepts related to the processes of global economic/social/political integration, such as regionalism, global governance, interdependence;  Be exposed to the main controversies resulted from globalization processes, e.g., trade liberalization and the 'race to the bottom', human rights and sovereignty, global market forces and the goal of nature conservation, and democratic deficit in global institutions; --Have the ability to form independent idea about the causes, impact and controversies of globalization by applying the key concepts covered in the course;  Have the ability to related the macro-level factors of globalization to current affairs in Hong Kong society.

title: Social Work and Cultural Diversity
requirements: UGEC2684 is double-coded with SOWK2202. ;Not for Social Work Majors; and students who have taken SOWK2202.;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2684 is double-coded with SOWK2202.)  This course provides students with fundamental and systematic knowledge on issues related to ethnic and cultural diversity. Apart from introducing contemporary theories and conceptual perspectives about cultural sensitivity and cultural intelligence, this course will also highlight major discourses and challenges concerning access, equity, social inclusiveness, cultural assimilation and integration which have substantial impact on ethnic minorities as well as social harmony. Through participation in small group projects, guided community tours, and face-to-face interaction with different ethnic groups, students will be able to develop an awareness of the differences in values, beliefs, life-style and interpersonal relatedness between themselves and people of other ethnic background. Basic skills, knowledge and attitude required of cultural intelligence, equal-opportunity legislations, social policies, service provision in meeting the needs of ethnic minorities, and measures to promote mutual acceptance and social inclusiveness will be discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1.            Acquire knowledge of the key concepts and theoretical perspectives of multiculturalism, related social policies and service delivery system; 2.            Apply an intercultural perspective to understand the struggles, challenges and socio-cultural barriers of ethnic groups in Hong Kong. 3.            Evaluate the impact of culture on individuals and/or groups’ values, beliefs, behaviours, attitudes, preferences and life pursuits; 4.            Develop awareness in cultural sensitivity and acquire cultural competence as well as intercultural intelligence

title: Social Innovation and Social Change for Good
requirements: UGEC2686 is double-coded with SOWK2204.;Not for Social Work Majors; and students who have taken SOWK2204.;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2686 is double-coded with SOWK2204.)  This course prepares students to learn from the emerging practices of social innovations in tackling with challenges in social, economic, cultural and political development in Hong Kong, the Greater China region and beyond. Students will acquire analysis, knowledge and strategies of social innovations, the processes of social change in creating social values. The scope of social innovations includes that of social entrepreneurs or social innovators in NGOs, communities, social movements, non-profit organizations, and business as well as the public sector. The course will examine cases of social innovations that have catalyzed important positive social change through the market, the nonprofit sector, the community, the public sector as well as the spaces among those four sectors. Experiential learning will be integrated along the course delivery, such as programmme visits, dialogue with social entrepreneurs, staff members or service users. Students are encouraged to experience these operations, so as to analyze the development issues, the social values and innovations in offering practical solutions to poverty and social inequalities, unemployment and livelihood, civic and community engagement, fair trade as well as sustainable development. The course will provide inspirations as well as know-hows for students who are concerned about the articulation of local with global and regional issues and like to develop innovative actions to change the society for good.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to ·         Realise how social innovations work to target social issues, creating social values through innovative strategies in various sectors as well as cross sectoral collaboration; ·         Recognize the basic know-hows of social innovation such as design thinking, community or civic engagement, collaboration, prototyping and lean start-up; ·         Apprehend how social innovation leverage their work and impact to catalyze changes in the broader community, economy or political sphere. ·         Critically evaluate how social innovation can fulfil the objectives of coping with the challenges in the social, economic, cultural and political spheres. ·         Acquire personal experience and prepare to taking own responsibilities as global citizen and ready to be social innovator / social entrepreneur in tackling the local, regional and global development challenges.
syllabus: v  Development of Social Innovation in Hong Kong Regionally and Globally o   What is Social Innovation? o   Issues of  social, economic, culture and political development and Social Innovations o   Development of Social Innovation in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Mainland China, South Korea, Europe and US v  Defining Social Innovations o   Contesting definitions in Social Innovations o   Defining features of Social Innovations: social justice, empowerment, social capital, community engagement, design thinking, collaboration, etc. o   Generic social innovation processes: prompts and inspirations, imagining solutions, creativity and innovation, participation, prototyping and pilots, resource mobilization and start-ups, sustainability and scaling up o   Deep scaling and transformative social innovation v  Social Economy: From Social Enterprise to Social Solidarity Economy   o   Business model and social economy model o   From Corporate Social Responsibility to Social Enterprise o   From Social Solidarity Economy to Eco-village v  Social Innovations and the Environment o   Greening the Economy and Society o   Sustainable cities and human settlement o   Food security and small holder empowerment v  Social Innovations in the Public Sector o   How policy can maximize citizen participation o   Participatory budgeting and planning o   Policy environment for social innovations   v  Site Visits to Social Innovations in HK v  Case Study of Social Entrepreneurship: Dialogue Experiences v  The social, economic, political and cultural impact of Social Innovations o   Defining and measuring Impact o   Deep scaling and scaling up impacts o   Transformative Social Innovations v  Pursuing Social Innovations for the Global Futures

title: Politics and Current Affairs
requirements: Not for Government and Public Administration Majors.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: Political analyses of international and local current affairs. Selected issues will be discussed from both theoretical and practical perspectives. Part of the course may take the form of debate. The purpose is to provide students with the necessary political knowledge for critical analysis of current affairs.
outcome: Being a course of general education, instead of in-depth professional, after taking the course,  -         Students are expected to have their own insight on current issues  -         Students are expected to understand basic concepts of mass media and politics, e.g. mediocracy, globalization, left/ right, unilateralism, etc. -         Students are expected to be able to give critical argument against dominant view in any issue  -         Students are expected to be able write well-established analytical article to comment current issues  -         Students are expected to expand their English vocabulary about current issues -         Students are expected to learn speech skill from the instructor
syllabus: COURSE DESCRIPTION This course will focus on political concepts applied on major current affairs, local and international, as they arise. For this term we will start with the controversies surrounding the Star Ferry clock tower saga, the Chief Executive election and the Ching Cheong trial. The on-going global war on terrorism and Saddam Hussein's execution will also be covered later.   On top of breaking issues, regular topics to be covered are in the order of: - China and HK - China and Taiwan - China and the World Trade Organisation (WTO) - Globalisation - Amercia and the World   Please note this course will largely be conducted in English. Do decide whether you are linguistically up to it after the first couple of classes. Subsequent complaints that the standard of English used is too high will not be entertained.    MARKING SYSTEM 1.      On-line course web forum participation - 20% for all 2.      Mid-term exam (1 hour) - 20% (269R), 10% (279R) (Choose 1 out of 3 questions and answer in essay form, in either Chinese or English, with no more than 700 words) 3.      Class quiz (3 quizzes, 3 multiple-choice questions per quiz) - 30% (269R) - 15% (279R) 4.      Tutorial - 25% (279R ONLY) 5.      Final exam - 30% for all   QUIZ/MID-TERM EXAM TIME-TABLE Quiz 1 Quiz 2 Quiz 3 + ONE REPLACEMENT QUIZ (The replacement quiz is ONLY for anyone who has missed ONE quiz previously.) Mid-term exam   ASSIGNED READING No textbooks required. Weekly reading list largely of newspaper and magazine articles will be assigned.   COURSE CALENDAR (Revised)   Introduction A rough political overview China and HK + current affairs 1 China and HK + current affairs 2   (QUIZ 1**) China and Taiwan + current affairs 1 China and Taiwan + current affairs 2 China and WTO + current affairs 1 China and WTO + current affairs 2   (QUIZ 2**) Globalisation + current affairs 1 Globalisation affairs 2 America and the World + current affairs   (MID-TERM EXAM**) Roundup 1   (QUIZ 3 + REPLACEMENT QUIZ **) Roundup 2

title: Mission-driven Social Enterprise
requirements: UGEC2693 is double-coded with SOWK2203. ;Not for Social Work Majors; and students who have taken SOWK2203. ;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2693 is double-coded with SOWK2203.) This course introduces to students the field of mission-driven social enterprise, which aims to achieve a balance between meaningful social returns as well as sustainable or competitive financial returns through their products, services and other business practices. Through examining the best practices in social entrepreneurship, it also stimulates students to explore how social enterprise can affect policy and facilitate system change. Experiential learning elements such as visiting social enterprises and having dialogue with social entrepreneurs, staff members or service users will be arranged in order to let students experience its operation, understand its practice as well as to enable students in realizing its possibilities in offering solutions to education, healthcare, environment, workforce development, international development and other societal issues. The course is valuable to students who may want to design or lead a mission-driven social enterprise, or want to contribute time and energy to help build the social sector through this emerging field.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to ·         Understand how social entrepreneurs work to blend disparate goals, how and why social enterprises successfully fuse purpose and personal passion in business, and how visions and values are embedded in organizational culture; ·         Be familiar with a variety of approaches and tools to measure organizational performance and social impact of social enterprise. ·         Examine the key methods, strategies and models for social enterprises to succeed; ·         Understand the dimensions and models of social entrepreneurship and the strategies on fundraising, financial management, opportunity seeking, social marketing, alliance building, etc. ·         Apprehend how social enterprises leverage their work and impact to influence policy and the community; Critically evaluate how social enterprise can fulfil the objectives of meeting economic, ecological and social needs.

title: Youth Problem in Modern Society
requirements: Not for Sociology Majors; and students who have taken SOCI2110.;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: This course explores some of the major issues concerning the role of the youth and the problems confronting them in modern society. The nature of the conventional wisdom of the “youth problem” is critically examined, with the help of concepts and theories in sociology and related fields. By the end of the course, students are expected to gain more understanding of the nature of the phenomenon of problematization of youth, and to look beyond common sense or public perception on current social issues related to the youth in modern society. More importantly, youth problems can jeopardize the sustainable development of youth. [For example, education inequality (SDG4 Quality Education) and inadequate school-to-work transition (SDG8 Decent Work and Economic Growth) could impact on youth poverty (SDG1 No Poverty) as a result.] A broader and deeper understanding of various facets of problematization can inform how youth should be empowered to attain sustainable development in modern society.

title: Environmentalism and Environmental Education
requirements: UGEC2710 is double-coded with EDUC2130. ;Not for students majoring in EDU; not for CLED and ELED Majors; and students who have taken EDUC2130.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2710 is double-coded with EDUC2130.) The course is aimed at preparing students as global and future citizens who not only have critical understandings of the environmental issues, but also the capabilities and attitudes to take an active role in tackling the issues and educating for the environment. This course is structured around key issues pertaining to environmentalism and environmental education, including climate changes, sustainability, green groups and environmental curriculum and teaching at schools. Using an issue-inquiry approach, course participants will be led to critically reflect on the issues from various perspectives: philosophical, scientific, social and educational. The different approaches to environmental education in the Western and Chinese communities will be explored in the contexts of eastern and western cultures. A field trip is included to provide experiential education in the environment.
outcome: At the end of this course, students will be able to:     understand the complexity of environmental issues as an interplay between science, politics, values, economy, education and social development;    critically understand key environmental issues at both local and global levels;    actively participate in the discourse and actions concerning environmental issues;    recognize different approaches to environmental education and critically analyze their strengths and constraints;    understand the relations between environmental education and cultural differences;    actively participate in environmental education both inside and outside the school systems;    appreciate and to live an environmentally-friendly lifestyle
syllabus: How do people start to care about the environment - a historical understanding of environmentalism and its definition    A framework for understanding environmental issues    Is climate change a myth or hoax - understanding the science behind and its limitations    Why don’t people take climate change seriously - consequences and solutions of climate change    What’s wrong with the countries – politics and the environment    What’s wrong with our society – modern capitalism and the environment    Is sustainable development a myth?    What’s wrong with human beings – environmental ethics?    What’s wrong with the environmental advocacy groups - myths of some environmental activities?    What's wrong with our education - aims and approaches of environmental education?    How do different countries approach environmental education –Hong Kong, China, Taiwan and others    Overview of issues related to environmental problems and environmental education    Field trip to a site related to current environmental issues in Hong Kong, such as North East development farmland, EcoPark, Fung Yuen butterfly convervation centre.

title: Hong Kong Cinema Through a Global Lens
requirements: Not for Cultural Studies; Religious Studies Majors; and students who have taken CURE2030 or UGEC2241. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: The University of Hong Kong (HKU), The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK), The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST), and The Hong Kong Polytechnic University (PolyU) are partners in a joint project entitled “The Responsive Universities: Appreciating Content Sharing in General Education”, which is funded by the UGC Funding Scheme for Teaching and Learning Related Proposals in the 2016-19 Triennium. Arising from this joint project, the four universities enter into an Agreement for Collaboration in Cross-institutional General Education Course Enrolment, under which students in the four universities can enrol in a list of designated General Education courses respectively offered by the four universities. This course, offered by The University of Hong Kong, is one of the designated courses under the Agreement.By confirming your enrolment of the course, you agree to give consent to CUHK in sharing your personal data among the partner institution of the Agreement for Collaboration in Cross-institutional Course Enrolment among HKU, CUHK, HKUST and PolyU, and to the partner institution for releasing your grades or other information relating to your study of the course to CUHK.In an age where cross-cultural interactions and global traffics are frequent, Hong Kong cinema cannot be regarded merely as a local cinema. It is an interesting site where complex global processes can be traced. Flows of capital, film personnel, technologies, ideas and creativity are vibrantly circulating inside and outside the cultural industry of filmmaking, resulting in phenomena such as transnational co-productions and cross-cultural cooperations. These dynamic processes are inflected in characterization, plot development, and space-time configurations on Hong Kong screens. This course takes students on an interdisciplinary exploration of the local-global interactions from a variety of approaches. With a selection of Hong Kong films, the course aims to help students attain a thorough understanding of the two-way relationship between the local, popular entertainment and the global film scene by investigating the major questions concerning globalization. Film critics and scholars will be invited to conduct guest lectures.

title: Design on the Future: Sustainability of the Built Environment
requirements: Not for Architectural Studies; Geography & Resource Management; Urban Studies Majors; and students who have taken GRMD2401/ UGEC2201/ UGEC2171. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: The University of Hong Kong (HKU), The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK), The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST), and The Hong Kong Polytechnic University (PolyU) are partners in a joint project entitled “The Responsive Universities: Appreciating Content Sharing in General Education”, which is funded by the UGC Funding Scheme for Teaching and Learning Related Proposals in the 2016-19 Triennium. Arising from this joint project, the four universities enter into an Agreement for Collaboration in Cross-institutional General Education Course Enrolment, under which students in the four universities can enrol in a list of designated General Education courses respectively offered by the four universities. This course, offered by The University of Hong Kong, is one of the designated courses under the Agreement.By confirming your enrolment of the course, you agree to give consent to CUHK in sharing your personal data among the partner institution of the Agreement for Collaboration in Cross-institutional Course Enrolment among HKU, CUHK, HKUST and PolyU, and to the partner institution for releasing your grades or other information relating to your study of the course to CUHK.The course is intended to inspire thinking about the way we should construct our living environments in future, in order to find the most sustainable balance. It explores a range of broad issues including: population and urbanization, materials resources, and human systems (such as transportation and public health), in order to understand the concept of ‘sustainable development’. It evaluates the different media and strategies that people have used / are using to advocate for more sustainable approaches to the environment and community.This course is run using a ‘flipped classroom’ pedagogy. Students are required to undertake up to one hour of pre-class activities (typically watching and responding to on-line course videos) in preparation for the classroom sessions which are run in workshop format involving a wide range of group activities and interactive exercises. There are no tutorials in this course. The on-line components deliver the bulk of the course content, in class activities are designed to develop understanding of the content, to explore contexts and interconnections, and to actively apply it to different scenarios.

title: Grand Challenges for Global Citizens in the 21st Century
requirements: Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: The 21st century is an era of global connectedness with urgent, complex and intricate problems which can only be tackled by coordinated and concerted efforts of all people of the world. In 2015, United Nations member states adopted unanimously 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to address the world’s most pressing challenges, including ending poverty and hunger, protecting the planet from environmental degradation and climate change, building sustainable communities where people can have decent work, enjoy peaceful, and healthy lives, and be free from discrimination, fear and violence. The course aims at enhancing global awareness and fostering global citizenship by introducing some of the most salient SDGs. CUHK experts will lead students to explore global issues such as global warming, hunger and sustainable agriculture, challenge of big data and/or artificial intelligence, urbanization and sustainable living, poverty and income disparity, and conflict of cultures and terrorism. Students will learn to identify global issues, analyse the complexity and interdependence of these challenges, and assess critically the role SDGs play in addressing global challenges. They will also reflect on their responsibilities of being global citizens, and discuss with their peers to formulate possible solutions to make the world a better place.

title: Cultural Perspectives of Chinese Medicine
requirements: Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: The establishment and development of Chinese Medicine have been greatly inspired by traditional Chinese culture, including the ancient Chinese philosophy, religious doctrines and history. This course will provide the opportunity for students to possess a deeper understanding of the association between traditional Chinese culture and Chinese Medicine. The difference between Chinese and Western cultures will also be discussed.
outcome: 完成本課程後，期望學生能夠︰ - 提高對中華民族傳統文化的認知 - 描述中華文化(包括中國古代哲學、宗教、文學、歷史、民族、飲食)與中醫學及識別中醫學的關係 - 比較並指出中西醫學的異同 - 評價中華文化在中醫學中的地位 - 分析各種與中醫相關的文化現象與中醫學的連繫     (
syllabus: 講授內容 (一) 中醫的概念﹕中醫、中藥與中國文化 概括介紹中國醫學的起源、形成、發展、學術特點及與中國傳統文化的密切關係，討論嶺南中醫藥文化以及中西醫的比較。   (二) 中醫藥與儒、釋、道家文化以及《易經》的關係  簡述中醫藥文化與儒、釋、道三家以及易經的關係：儒家的仁、禮、中庸之道與中醫藥環環相扣，相互參照；釋家「醫方明」與中醫理論相互吸收和影響；道家學說不少與中醫理論類通，同樣強調人與大自然的關係和天人相應；  《黃帝內經》對自然和人體的認識，及其辨證理論，一脈相承自《易經》。  (三) 文學與中醫 以儒通醫。古代學者如陶潛、陸游、蘇軾、羅貫中、曹雪芹等都曾經行醫或有深厚的中醫造詣。   中醫不少著作是用詩、詞、歌、賦形式撰寫的，讀者容易記憶，文學著作亦有豐富的中醫內容。本節選讀唐詩、宋詞、紅樓夢、三國演義等文學著作，欣賞其中包含的中醫宇宙觀、生命觀、並討論其中所列舉的藥物，病案。 (四) 中醫理論之應用﹕飲食、養生之中醫文化 從簡介舌診、臟腑辨證、君臣佐使組方原理，先讓學生認識中醫診治方法，再以飲食和養生兩方面闡述中華寶庫之一----中醫保健之道。食療：飲食養生，家居實用補藥，涼茶及保健湯水。養生：四季養生法，十二時辰養生法，休憩養生與七情養生。保健、養顏：按摩、穴位和藥膳。

title: Applied Ethics
requirements: Not for Philosophy Majors; and students who have taken PHIL3253 or UGED2855. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: A survey of major moral debates that shows how philosophical thought can be brought to bear upon contemporary issues. This course will focus on such moral problems as arising from abortion, our treatment of animals, criminal punishment, death penalty, euthanasia, and sex. Students will learn normative ethical theories and reflect on how these theories can contribute to the resolution of the above-mentioned problems. Students will also be encouraged to develop their own judgments in a critical manner,
outcome: Understand the nature of applied ethics.    Recognize the characteristics and importance of some main problems of applied ethics.    Reflect on how to resolve these problems of applied ethics.    Understand each problem of applied ethics in its own right, and whether a particular problem must be resolved.    Identify the characteristics and value of ethical theories.    Explain and assess different moral stances in a perspicuous, non-doctrinaire way.

title: Sexuality and Culture
requirements: UGEC2853 is double-coded with GDRS2002. ;Not for Philosophy Majors; and students who have taken GDRS2002. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2853 is double-coded with GDRS2002.)  This course aims at an interdisciplinary approach to the study of human sexuality and culture. Three main areas will be discussed: (1) ideas of sexuality: Chinese and Western conception of sexuality, modern theories of sexuality; (2) sexuality and ethics: ethical issues of sexual relationships; and (3) sexuality and society: gender problem; issues relating to homosexuality, pornography, and AIDS.
outcome: Identify and recognize the ideas of sex and sexuality in Western and Chinese culture.    Discuss sexual issues openly and intellectually without any taboo.    Identify and reflect on various media representations of sex.    Appreciate the complexity of sexuality in modern society regarding homosexuality, feminism, etc.

title: Animals and Society : A philosophical approach
requirements: Not for Philosophy Major. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: This course examines the social issues of animal from the philosophical perspectives. What are the key differences humans and other animals? Is it ethical to raise and slaughter animals for food, conduct tests on, and buying or keeping animals as pets? How ought one to respond to unethical laws on animals? What are the social impacts of these actions? Students will develop an interdisciplinary perspective in the fields of animal studies, ethical theory, sociology and environmental philosophy by understanding how ancient and contemporary philosophers, sociologist, environmental scientists, ecologists, activists, and journalists have responded to key ethical questions concerning animal rights and its social implication. Topics to be discussed include: animal-machines, ethical meat eating, radical vegetarianism, and the evolution of pets.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  cite the major arguments in the current philosophical debates over the social and moral status of nonhuman animals, and understand the strengths and weakness of each;  recount the historical, scientific and cultural contexts of the debate;  discuss the broad range of animal exploitation and the moral issues that each form of it raises;  form a conclusion about the ethics of using animals and defend it with a strong, logical argument.

Normative topics will include the following: Should homosexuality and/or abortion be legalized? Should death penalty ever be used? Analytical topics will be: Hong Kong's legal system (with an emphasis on criminal proceedings), the concept of law, critiques of law.

title: Hong Kong Society
requirements: Not for Sociology Majors; and students who have taken GEJC1020, SOCI1201 or 2104.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum) ).
description: From the “borrowed time and borrowed place”, Hong Kong has evolved into a global city with its own identity. Since the 1950s, the city experienced an economic miracle, withstood numerous financial crises, and is in the process of economic restructuring. Politically, it has turned from “the last Colony” of Great Britain into a Special Administrative Region of the PRC. Culturally, the flourishing Canto pop-culture coincides with the emergence of a local identity. Using a sociological perspective, this course investigates the impact of these profound changes on individuals, families, ethnic groups, and society.

title: Economic Reform and Social Impacts in China
requirements: UGEC2883 is double-coded with SOCI2106.;Not for Sociology Majors; and students who have taken GESC2118, SOCI2106 or UGEA2190.;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2883 is double-coded with SOCI2106.)  This course is to examine the economic reforms and its social consequences in China from different theoretical perspectives and to probe into the problems, difficulties and constraints facing China’s economy and society. After taking this course, students should be able to understand social impacts of economic reforms from a wide range of aspects, such as labour (SDG1 No poverty, SDG5 Gender equality, SDG8 Decent work and economic growth, SDG10 Reducing inequality, SDG12 Responsible consumption and production), migration (SDG1, 5, 8, 10), gender (SDG5, 10), environment (SDG13 Climate Action), grassroots participation, human rights and civil society, and explore solutions to these problems. The course will highlight the relevancy of these social aspects to achieving sustainable development goals, for example reducing poverty and inequality, decent work and economic growth, responsible consumption and production, and climate action.
outcome: Students should be able to explain the main aspects of economic reform and social impacts in contemporary China.  Students should be able to identify the key social science concepts and theories through which the underlying forces changing China today are studied.  Students should be able to apply the theories and methods to analyze the close interaction and dilemma between society, economy, and humanistic concerns.

Based on the visit, they will give a presentation and submit a project report.

title: Money, Land and Housing
requirements: Not for Urban Studies Majors. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: When money is fiat, land is scarce, housing becomes a good hedge of inflation. However, when housing is both an investment capital as well as a necessity, the city is split into an owner-renter dichotomy, with the former preferring an increase of housing prices but just the opposite for the latter. When the pendulum of housing price swings to one side, housing capital can result in negative equity, asset bubble, or even financial crisis. Swinging to the other end, housing can become unaffordable, even if public housing or subsidy can be provided. Decent living environment and sustainable community are the concerns of cities. This introduction course explores the reasons of the housing price fluctuations and the implications of the dichotomy on the city lives.
outcome: Explain the relationships between money, land and housing;    Understand factors determining land and housing prices;    Identify the effects of housing price fluctuations on financial stability and wealth inequality;    Appreciate the effect of monetary and land policies on housing affordability;    Draw implications from the owner-renter dichotomy on the housing policy; and    Analyse the sustainability issues of public housing and cooperative housing systems.
syllabus: The following topics are included in the course: PART I: Relationships between money, land and housing  Why housing can be a good hedge of inflation?  How does the monetary policy affect the housing market?  Why interest rate and inflation rate affect housing price?  Is high land price or restrictive land supply a cause of high housing price?  How does the housing policy affect the housing market? PART II: Social implications of housing issues  What is the owner-renter dichotomy of housing?  What are the implications of the housing dichotomy on our city lives?  Why housing can become unaffordable?  How does housing price fluctuation affect financial stability and wealth inequality?  Why are there housing cycles and housing bubbles?  What is property hegemony? PART III:  Is public housing or cooperative housing a solution?  A sustainable housing policy.

title: Urban Regeneration
requirements: Not for Urban Studies Majors.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000 or UGFN1000 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum).
description: Urban regeneration is a subject of public concern as it is a source of housing supply and a daily activity to upkeep and revitalize the built environment of the older neighbourhoods in Hong Kong today. It also encompasses building redevelopment, rehabilitation, conservation and on a larger scale, urban restructuring. On the social side, uprooting the existing residents and their social networks, together with the issue of compensation has long been causing major public concerns and criticisms. The issue is further complicated by the recent debate on the social responsibilities and economic sustainability of the URA. On the economic side, affected property owners and tenants are concerned about compensation while there are effects on the revitalized economy of the area particularly in major comprehensive redevelopment projects. Redevelopment in old urban areas is also important for developers and the development industry, given the scarcity of urban developable land. On the heritage side, both the hardware of historic buildings and the software of traditional businesses, arts and culture could be affected but regeneration might also be a positive intervention. This course aims at examining the subject of Urban Regeneration comprehensively and critically by explaining the dilemmas, controversies, and concerns revolving around the urban regeneration process in Hong Kong.

title: Understanding Urban Agriculture
requirements: Not for Urban Studies Majors. ;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: Urban space is often perceived as space for industrial and commercial activities. In a deindustrialized city like Hong Kong, people seem to identify urban space with consumption activities. However, following recent social movements related to agriculture in Choi Yuen Village and Northeast New Territories New Development Area, concerns are growing in Hong Kong over the significance of urban agriculture. Globally speaking, urban agriculture has been studied and implemented for decades, and its contributions to sustainable urban development is recognized by the United Nations (UN) in its New Urban Agenda. The 2016 New Urban Agenda are closely related to the 17 Sustainable Development Goals adopted by world leaders in 2015, as a response to the socio-economic and environmental crises faced by humankind. This course introduces the definition, evolution and applications of urban agriculture through sharing local and global experiences. Through lectures and fieldtrips, students will appreciate the multi-functionality of urban agriculture and its contribution to the building of sustainable and resilient city, for people’s life and livelihood. Among the 17 SDGs, the course aims to highlight Goals 2 (Zero Hunger), 6 (Clean Water and Sanitization), 11(Sustainable Cities and Communities) and 12 (Responsible Consumption and Production).
outcome: After taking the course, students are expected to: -Understand the development and diverse functions of urban agriculture; -Appreciate applications of urban agriculture in promoting more sustainable living; -Analyse the complexity behind urban agriculture initiatives in relation to social, economic, and environmental concerns; -Evaluate critically the local and global practices and policies of urban agriculture by the parameters suggested by the SDGs; -Mobilise their knowledge and imagination to create innovative ideas on promoting SDGs in different communities; -Act to combat climate change and build resilience by designing and constructing edible landscapes in CUHK campus according to the principles of SDGs.
syllabus: Module 1: Why do we farm in urban environment? 1.       Definitions of urban agriculture (abbreviated as UA below) ·             To define UA in terms of geographical location, types of economic activities and production systems, etc. 2.       Historical development of urban agriculture ·             To introduce different applications of UA and their contribution behind urban sustainability. 3.       Urban agriculture in action I (CUHK farm tour) ·             To observe the different types of farming practices in CUHK promoting resilient communities and climate-smart agriculture.   Module 2: How does multifunctional urban agriculture tackles with urban sustainability challenges? 4.       Food regimes, productivism and multifunctional urban agriculture ·             To unpack the nature and causes of global food system transition through the perspectives of food regimes, productivism and multifunctionality. 5.       Economic functions of urban agriculture ·             To examine the potential economic benefits of UA, such as providing a wide range of job opportunities and utilizing urban space efficiently for achieving zero hunger. 6.       Environmental functions of urban agriculture ·             To examine the potential environmental benefits of UA, such as reducing food mile and recycling of natural resources such as clean water. 7.       Urban agriculture in action II (Visit to a community farm in Tin Shui Wai) ·             To explore how UA encourages more inclusive and resilient communities with grassroot families in Hong Kong’s local contexts. 8.       Social functions of urban agriculture ·             To examine the potential social benefits of UA, such as promoting food education to reduce food wastage and improving public physical and mental wellbeing.   Module 3: What makes a successful application of urban agriculture? 9.       Reflecting on the sustainability of UA development: Entrepreneurial city and urban agriculture ·             To critically evaluate the sustainability behind different cities’ UA attempts to achieve resilience after economic recession or to promote a green city branding. 10.   Resilient communities and sustainable cities under food crises ·             To study how people and cities survive a food crisis through revolving food system and promoting local and sustainable agriculture. 11.   Urban implications of agrotechnology under limited natural resources ·             To understand the rationale of sustainable agrotechnology and its applications to UA, e.g. water-saving farming methods including hydroponics. 12.   Development of urban agriculture in Hong Kong ·             To analyse how Hong Kong’s agriculture has evolved with respect to its functions to promoting a more sustainable urban food system. 13.   Ethical food consumption to shape a more sustainable city ·             To act on the wide possibilities to sustainable food system such as ethical food consumption, where the ethics behind could be advanced from political concern to care for the Earth.

title: Belt and Road for Collaborative Modernization
requirements:
UGEC2917 is double-coded with URSP2010. 
Not for Urban Studies Majors; and students who have taken URSP2010.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2917 is double-coded with URSP2010.)  The Belt and Road initiative (BRI) refers to the Silk Road Economic Belt and the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road. It is a significant development strategy proposed by the Chinese Government spanning approximately 60 countries in Asia, Eastern Europe, Middle East and Africa, with a total population of 4.4 billion. This initiative takes advantage of global transportation routes, core cities, and key ports to build international economic co-operation corridors. The effective operation and management of the BRI require collaboration among a broad range of disciplines comprising civil engineering, material science, government operations, economics and finance, social and political science, and environmental science. A critical and multi-disciplinary understanding of the BRI can provide insights into basic requirements, geopolitical impact, physical barriers, and sustainability potential of the infrastructural projects it proposes to undertake and help relevant stakeholders address large-scale and complex challenges in the lifecycle management of those infrastructure projects. This course involves forward-looking perspectives to assess, predict, influence and enhance the in/direct network effects and benefits of the BRI on the cities, urban systems and peoples of the Belt and Road region.
outcome: (1)    To explain the historical, economic and geopolitical background of the Belt and Road Initiative; (2)    To analyze economic, social, environmental, cultural and political forces, structures and processes associated with the Belt and Road Initiative; (3)    To evaluate the built environment and urban issues of Eurasian cities and how these may be improved by appropriate integration into the Belt and Road infrastructure; (4)    To apply Hong Kong’s world-class urban management practices to help the Belt and Road countries to maximize the benefits of network externality effects; (5)    To simulate and predict multi-scale spatial economic and urban outcomes of the Belt and Road infrastructure investments. (6)    To synthesize intercultural and global perspectives and to recommend ways to foster international cooperation, cultural diversity and integration.
syllabus: Introduction 1.       Globalization in Perspective: introduction of globalization as a term, process and ideology.     2.       Historical Silk Road: historical origins of the Silk Road; continuities and shifts in terms of Maritime Silk Road, interactions and encounters along the Silk Road.   Global Implications 3.       Geopolitical Shifts: branding and popularizing the Belt and Road Initiative; imperial histories and ambitions informing the initiative. 4.       Eastern and Western Perspectives: the opportunities and challenges arising from Belt and Road Initiative with reference to the European Recovery Program; the geopolitical theories of Alfred Mahan, Halford Mackinder and Henry Kissinger; the philosophy of Confucius and Taoists.   Facilities Connectivity 5.       Construction Management in BRI countries: risk management in international construction joint ventures and overseas development institute; large-scale transnational high-speed railway construction projects. 6.       Green and Sustainable Urbanization: In search of better livability in BRI cities: Liveability in dense and vertical cities; green finance; carbon auditing and carbon trading; green strategies for achieving sustainable development goals.   Unimpeded Trade 7.       Trading, Logistic, and Professional Service: Hong Kong as regional BRI centre for trading, logistic and professional services; manufacture shifting and upgrading experience in ASEAN economies. 8.       The Energy Market: energy market opportunities and uncertainties in Northeast, Southeast, Central Asia and Africa; global oil and gas markets; renewable and sustainable energy goals.   Financial Integration 9.       The Bond Market: infrastructure financing; international bond market and Hong Kong’s debt market; corporate social responsibility on Green Bond Issuance; the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank and the Silk Road Fund. 10.    International Settlement: currency wars and special drawing rights; consumerism and RMB internationalization; Hong Kong as the offshore RMB centre; the New Development Bank.   Regional Responses 11.    Middle East: geopolitics and energy nexus; religious and national concerns. 12.    Central and Eastern Europe: rail and maritime connectivities; integrating trade and resisting xenophobia. 13.    India: regional rivalry, economic integration and border disputes

title: History of Hong Kong: From Colony to Special Administrative Region
requirements: Not for History Majors; and students who have taken GESC2150, GLBS3406. HIST2200, UGEC1542, 2935 or 3542.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: This course examines the development of Hong Kong from its founding as a British colony from an historical perspective, with emphasis on the transformation of its social structure, cultural role, political system, economic pattern, and its position in modern China.
outcome: This course aims to help students relate their experiences to history. It presents the history of the entire period of British rule in Hong Kong in a structural and contextual manner. Students are expected to develop an appreciation for changes in Hong Kong society through times. They are encouraged to read critically some selected works on Hong Kong history and to articulate their own arguments and opinions in a reasoned manner. In short, this course helps student to   (1)   enhance the understanding of local history and the relationship between modern China and Hong Kong. (2)   acquire & comprehend historical facts in various aspects, such as political structure, characteristics of social changes, economic development and Sino-Hong Kong relations. (3)   interpret historical evidence through inferring, comparing and contrasting a variety of primary and secondary sources. (4)   broaden the intellectual perspective. (5)   apply historical knowledge & methodology in life and careers and other fields of study.
syllabus: (1)       導論、歷史沿革 (Introduction & Hong Kong in Outline) (2)       鴉片戰爭與香港開埠 (The Opium War & the Cessation of Hong Kong to Britain) (3)       殖民體系的建立與演進 (The Colonial Setting and Development) (4)       華人社會與組織 (The Chinese Community and Social Structure) (5)       教育的百花齊放 (The Development of Hong Kong Education) (6)       社會運動的萌芽與發展 (Strike and Boycott: The Development of Social Movements) (7)       香港淪陷及日佔時期 (The Battle of Hong Kong and the Japanese Occupation) (8)       戰後香港 (Post-war Hong Kong) (9)       暴動歲月 (Riots and Reforms) (10)   麥理浩時代 (The Maclehose Years) (11)   中英談判及聯合聲明 (Sino-British Negotiations and the Joint Declaration) (12)   過渡期政治變化 (Political Changes in Transitional Period) (13)   總結：誰是香港人、誰人的香港史？(Conclusion: Who are the Hongkongers & How Hong Kong History can be Written?)

title: Environmental Crises and Cultures of Survival
requirements: UGEC2950 is double-coded with ANTH2380. ;Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2380.;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2950 is double-coded with ANTH2380.)  This course pays attention to the environment and its relation with human experiences. Through the lens of environment, we bring human diversity into presence, examining ways of life of peoples—from Indonesia highlander to Tokyo urbanites—and their words and deeds to tackle crises of planetary scale—climate change, nuclear disaster, air pollution, waste, deforestation. Facing these crises, can anthropological inquiry of the environment help us to explore a humanity that can accommodate living beings of all kind? How can such inquiry inspire us to make changes that create a world we can live together? We’ll follow these trails in the environment to look for engagement and conversation: cultural perception on the origin of agriculture, resource use and religious belief, debating traditional ecological knowledge, globalization and state intervention, environmental justice, land dispossession, waste and pollution, disaster and extreme environment. Through ethnographies of people who are struggling to survive, this course asks why they are pushed into poverty, how their resources being exploited, what they do to fight for justice; it covers SDGs related to the issues of sustainable agriculture (SDG2), tacking climate change (SDG13) and promoting peace, justice and institutional accountability (SDG16).
outcome: 1. Understand how humans have engaged the environment historically and cross-culturally; 2. Examine the relationship between the environment, local communities and the state in the present world through issues including deforestation, climate change, and nuclear disaster; 3. Explore contemporary environmental crises to cultivate sensitivity to possible forms of resistance and action from local and global perspectives.
syllabus: Part I: Cultural Knowledge of the Environment  1. Cultural Perceptions of the Origin of Agriculture  2. Religious Belief in Resource Use  3. Traditional Ecological Knowledge  4. Materialist Conception of Nature (I)  5. Materialist Conception of Nature (II)—State Intervention and Globalization     Part II: Contemporary Culture of Environmental Politics  Topics of contemporary environmental crises are contemplated through case studies and ethnographies of people who become vulnerable. We will cover related SDGs to explore possibilities of action to achieve a sustainable way of life for humans.  6. Extraction (SDG16)  - the cause of uneven distribution of environmental risks and how local communities struggle for survival and justice  7. Waste   8. Toxicity  9. Disaster and extreme environment (SDG16)  - the government’s immediate response to disaster and affected communities’ action to restore respectful life  10. Conservation (SDG2)   - the functioning of conservation agencies and the conflicts between conservation and local community  11. Climate Change (SDG 13)  - the impact of climate change to local ecology and people’s livelihood, their actions and adaptations  12. Conclusion—Rethinking Development (SDG 16)  - the insistence on productivity in modern societies, and the possibilities of sustainable future

title: Magic, Myth and the Supernatural
requirements: UGEC2960 is double-coded with ANTH2340. ;Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2340. ;Co-requisite: Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2960 is double-coded with ANTH2340.)  This course will examine phenomena often viewed as irrational and superstitious to see how they can be understood in cultural terms. All societies have some beliefs in another world, yet beliefs vary widely between societies. The course will examine traditional anthropological topics such as magic, traditional healing, divination, fengshui, witchcraft, and ghosts, as well as more recent issues such as ESP, psychokinesis, qigong, vampires, zombies, monsters, UFOs and alien abduction. The role of myth in modern society and the cultural creation of reality will be highlighted. The power of a cultural approach in explaining the supernatural and the limits of what science can explain will also be discussed.
outcome: Students taking this course will:              learn to see the cultural nature of reality and of the supernatural;              understand how many apparently irrational and bizarre beliefs make sense in their cultural contexts;              learn how to use critical thinking while at the same time being tolerant of other views;              develop a healthy scientific skepticism, while at the same time remaining open to new ideas;              be able to analyze other cases that will emerge later in life.
syllabus: Topics: Magic Rumors and Urban Legends Ghosts and Spirits Witchcraft and Evil Eye Divination Shamanism Traditional healing Vampires and Monsters UFOs and Alien Abduction Myths "Superstition," Relativism, and Science

title: Social Problems in China
requirements: Not for Sociology Majors and students who have taken SOCI2216.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000 or UGFN1000 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum).
description: (UGEC2963 is double-coded with SOCI2216.) China’s opening to the world has led to not only massive social and economic transformations, but also the emergence of social problems. This course explores some of these social problems, especially since the economic reform after 1978. The nature of these social problems and their possible causes will be critically examined, in the context of modernization, with the help of related concepts and theories in sociology. By the end of the course, students are expected to have a basic understanding of the major social problems in contemporary China and their implications for social and economic developments of China in the future.
outcome: 1. Students will be able to gain a basic intellectual understanding of the nature and possible causes of the major social problems faced by a changing China.  2. Students will be able to develop critical thinking on the public perception of social problems in China.  3. Students will be able to apply the theoretical perspectives and concepts gained from this course to analyze social problems they encounter in contemporary China.
syllabus: With the help of related concepts and theories in sociology, this course will critically examine the nature of some of the social problems and their possible causes faced by China under modernization.  The topics include:  1. Urbanization and migration  6. Social inequality  7. Social resistance  8. Aging population  9. Crime trends and responses of criminal justice system  10. Environmental problems  11. title: Gender in Asia
requirements: UGEC2970 is double-coded with ANTH2330. ;Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2330. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2970 is double-coded with ANTH2330.)  This course focuses on gender in the Asian region. A comparative approach will be taken to reflect diversity and resemblance, continuity and discontinuity, and historical and contemporary influences on gender within countries in the Asian region. Societies studied may vary from year to year, and may include Hong Kong, mainland China, India, Japan, Korea, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Chinese across societies. Gender issues and conditions will be examined within different contexts, covering such areas as language, class, work, family and kinship, health, sexuality, education, religion, development and politics.
outcome: 1.      Students learn to appreciate that in Asia, a vast and culturally diverse region, in an era of globalization and spread of consumerism and tourism, the concepts, roles and relations of gender in Asia are changing rapidly. Students will examine how gender as one of the guiding principles of social life takes various forms in different Asian cultures. 2.      Students will learn a cross-cultural perspective to understanding the similarities and differences, as well as the change and continuity in the region. 3.      A focus on how gender interacts with the family and marriage will challenge students to rethink taken-for-granted concepts and social behavior, and in the process develop critical thinking on such contested phenomena as public-private divide, the body and the social, religion, ethnicity, and class.
syllabus: I.                    Gender as social-cultural construct in Asia 1.      Introduction: Gender and Asia 2.      Conclusion: Power and modernity in Asia   II.                 Gender in East Asia 1.      Gender relations in Chinese societies 2.      Family and modernization in Korea 3.      Gender relations in Japan   III.               Gender in Southeast Asia 1.      Development and gendered livelihood in Southeast Asia 2.      Sex roles and class in Singapore 3.      Gendered work and mobility: Indonesians 4.      Changing genders in Thailand   IV.              Gender in South Asia 1.      Gender, politics, and economics in South Asia 2.      Gender and religion in India 3.      Nepalese in Hong Kong   Countries covered by the course alters from semester to semester. Examples are Malaysia, Vietnam and Sri Lanka.

title: Criminals and the Law
requirements: UGEC2983 is double-coded with SOCI2116.;Not for LLB, Sociology Majors; and students who have taken SOCI2116.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2983 is double-coded with SOCI2116.) Students enrolled in this cross-disciplinary course will address three basic questions: “why do people become criminals”, “who makes criminal law”, and “how is criminal law enforced”. Specifically, this course will include topics such as the social causes of criminal behaviour, the role of criminal law in social control, and the operation of the criminal justice system (their internal interaction and external interaction with other social organizations). Comparative and local empirical research will also be drawn to explore the crime problems and the development of criminal law and the criminal justice system in USA, PRC, Taiwan and Hong Kong. In addition, to strengthen the students’ understandings on the current criminal justice system, students will be given one field opportunity to directly experience police departments, courts or prisons in Hong Kong.
outcome: 1.        To recognize major data sources, methodological approaches and issues in the study of crime, law and criminal justice;2.        To identify diverse patterns and types of crime in the United States, mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan, and discuss their connection to processes of social change, social stratification and social control in the larger society;3.        To differentiate the major theories of crime, law and criminal justice；4.        To be able to apply concepts and theories in the student’s “hometown” community; 5.       To demonstrate analytical and critical-thinking skills through the application of concepts and theories, as well as a broadened and more appreciative view of self and the society in which we live.
syllabus: This course is an introduction of concepts and theories on crime, law and criminal justice system and their application to Chinese society. It will focus on how social structure and social policy could influence criminal behaviours and how society reacts to such behaviours. 1.        Overview of Crime, Law and Justice: subject matters and key research questions2.        Types of crime, crime patterns, and crime statistics (official data, self-report data, and victimization data)3.        Organization of crime, such as fencing networks and black society4.        Social change and crime trends5.        Theories to explain crime: deterrence, rational choice, disorganization, anomie, social learning, social control, opportunity/routine activity, labelling, and conflict theory etc.6.         Classical Thoughts on Law and Society7.        Law-making: state power and benefit groups; balance between liberty and public safety; penology8.        Law-processing: the role of law in social control; Paradigms and models of the criminal justice system9.        Police: operation, theories and research10.     Courts: operation, theories and research11.      Correction: operation, theories and research
